description: I love harding park, and it's a great course and I DID played there for over 20 years. Now they have raised the green fees so HIGH for locals that harding or TPC has eliminated all local traffic, and at almost 100$ green fees for locals and for out of towner's MAN it's like 200$ without a cart lame. the flexible pricing tee times suck! Have a nice day..
author: Alec L.

description:
I asked the pro shop how the greens were and he said they're very good but not 100% yet since they sanded them 4 weeks ago.  I went out there and checked the 9th and 18th greens and they were very good.  When we went out the the following Tuesday, all the greens were very sandy compared to the previous Friday.  It seemed as if they put more sand on the 9th and 18th green.  It was our first time there, so we were a bit disappointed.  Truth be told, that course is not the challenge I thought it would be.

It's a nice looking course and we may play it again - maybe.
author: Leon A.

description:
This is one of my sons favorite places to golf in city. Fleming 9 first. Then Harding 18. 
Clubhouse has great food very nice will be back. Thank you
author: Tina P.

description: Beautiful course but bring your own food and drinks for the course. You'll probably never see the beverage cart.
author: Jarrod D.

description:
This is a really tough review for me.  Played on 4/25/17. I love the game of golf and I love playing different courses. This was my first time here and I was pretty excited to play on a course that has hosted numerous PGA events, and I have heard a lot about TPC Harding Park.  

From Tee to Green, the conditions were fantastic. Great fairways.  We decided to walk the course, and the pull carts come with sand on each cart so it was nice to be able to fill the divots and not leave the course in bad shape for the people playing behind you.  It looks like they aerated the greens about 2-3 weeks before we arrived, so it was just on the tail end of getting back to full speed.  We left some putts short on the first few holes before adjusting, but the greens still rolled pretty good. 

The reason why this course didn't get higher reviews is 2 parts:
1) not being a Bay Area resident, the rate was $147 for a weekday tee time.  That's a little steep, but I'm willing to pay it if the experience matches the fee.  If you are an SF resident with a Resident Card (that you have to purchase from City Hall or something like that) you get a pretty big discount, and it would only cost you about $55.  Bay Area Residents get something in between, like $90-100.  Unfortunately, it didn't live up to the steep price tag for me.  See reason #2 below.
2)  As far as the course layout, its a very walkable course, and I actually enjoyed walking it.  But as far as the holes, there's nothing really memorable about a lot of the par 4s.  It felt repetitive and lacked variety.  Straightaway Par 4s were a very common theme, except for a few holes.  

So overall, there's nothing "wrong" with this course, but it just didn't have any "WOW" factor, except for the price tag.  Maybe I'm not understanding some of the history of this course, or maybe as a first timer I couldn't appreciate all the features and missed a bunch things because I was so focused on playing well, but after the round I felt like I could have a similar golf experience at other courses and pay 1/3 of the price.  If this was a $60 golf course, maybe more stars, but because of the very low price-to-enjoyment ratio, I give this place 2.5 stars, which I rounded up to 3.
author: Mr L.

description:
I've played at TPC Harding Park 18 years ago before the renovation, and many times after the renovation.  It's almost the same course but with nice grass and nice cart paths.  If you are not an SF resident then the green fee is really expensive for what you get and not really worth the money IMO.  
1. SF Resident the price = $68
2. Non-SF resident price but a Bay Area resident price = $102
3. Non-Bay Area resident price = $177  

These are weekend rates of course.  The course is cart path ONLY.  This is why you always see people walking the course, it is not worth paying $20 for a cart when you can't even drive on the grass.  The course is not extremely challenging but it would be a nice course if the green fee was $68 for everyone.  I kind of enjoy playing Presidio more just because of the price difference. ;)

On a side note, the PGA occasionally holds the President's Cup at TPC Harding Park and that is always fun.
author: Dean S.

description: Very well run by TPC... everything in great shape! Puny driving range. Only suggestion is allow carts on fairways... will speed up the round...
author: Kenneth F.

description: Beautiful park with a great golf course and driving range. Very easy to get to and not very crowded at all. Great prices for the driving range.
author: Michael L.

description: TPC Harding Park is awesome! The course is well maintained, staff super friendly and I've never been stuck behind slow players - even at Fleming 9 where you just walk on! I normally play at the Presidio (since it's close to my home) but when I need a break from the wet course, I enjoy heading down south, catching some sun and the wider and more forgiving fairways. I also couldn't say nicer things about the staff especially in the golf shop! Grayson has always been very helpful - sharing insight on the greens, his perspective on the game and encouraging newer players like myself!  If you're visiting the Bay Area, I'd prioritize golfing at this amazing spot. ‍
author: Nisha B.

description:
The course here is always in great shape! The greens are usually just perfect. I'd rate the course condition 8/10. 
My complaint is in regards to the price and employee interaction here. 

I know it's a TPC course but to charge over $157 for non-residents is atrocious. 
Even the resident rate w/o cart is $57.   
Way overpriced for a city course. 

Here's the worst part : Service and customer interaction.
You can easily sense a lot of ego and ignorance flying around here as soon as you walk in. Not a single smile. It's almost like they don't want people to go out and enjoy themselves. To keep it short, management needs to improve or change completely.

*Warning- Range Machine. 
I'd suggest you use cash if you can. Sometimes after swiping your card, the balls won't disperse. So then you swipe again thinking the first time didn't go through. Congrats, you've just been charged TWICE for 1 bucket of balls.  They need new a new machine.
author: Paul J.

description: Probably the best maintained muni I've ever played. The holes are long and wide open with very little hazards, which helps out us hackers. One knock for the cart-path-only play on the ENTIRE course and the rise of the machines carts that auto shut off if you deviate from the path by a few feet. Otherwise, well worth checking out if you can get a deal.
author: Ryan C.

description:
Not a bad course.  Unfortunately staff could use a refresher on customer service. 
Our foursome was playing on the heels of another group the whole time when a twosome came up behind us.  Per usual golfing edict we let them go ahead, then a group behind them skipped a couple holes and went in front of them.  This left us waiting, which was fine, we were enjoying our day.  Then an employee by the name Malcom drove up and started yelling at us, saying to pick it up, that we were 20 minutes behind ...... this was based on the golf carts GPS not by any complaints from any players.
We tried explaining to him what happened but, he just got argumentative.  We did nothing wrong and we weren't holding anyone up.  
I called and left a message to speak with a manager and have received no response.  I will update once I hear back from someone.  
I'm very disappointed in the disrespect we received as paying customers.
author: Nolan B.

description:
Threw a baby shower here yesterday and am so impressed with this place!  Gorgeous venue!  The service and food were outstanding!  We only had one guy helping us thru out the whole event but he was awesome and attentive - from handing out mimosas to arriving guests, to refilling the water dispenser, to making sure our food trays were never empty.  I honestly did not have very high expectations of the food so I was so pleasantly surprised that it was so good.  My Aunt and I were saying that the scones were some of the best of we have ever had!  They were not dry and crumbly but moist and so flavorful.  Scrambled eggs are hard to get right, especially in mass quantity.  They're usually dry and over cooked but these were not.  They were so moist.  I am so happy we went with this venue!
One suggestion I would make to them would be to have attendants in golf carts available in various areas of the parking lot when there's another event going on on the same day, like a tournament.  There would have been ample parking but since there was a tournament as well yesterday, parking was super hard.  My sister, who was the guest of honor and heavily pregnant, had to park close to the entrance, outside the gates.  The walk from there to the clubhouse is a pretty long walk for non pregnant people so was extra long and hard for my sister.  Would have been nice to have an attendant drive her to the clubhouse on a golf cart.  Would be nice also for those who wear high heels and carrying gifts.  Other than that, I would highly recommend TPC Harding Park to host your events!
author: Doreen C.

description:
The course is mediocre at best and not worth the high prices charged to out of towners and even Bay Area residents. The cypress trees are dying and being removed and with them the picturesque scene you would get from playing there. Much better experiences and deals are found elsewhere outside of the city (Eagle vines, Wente Vineyards, Half Moon Bay, etc). The newly redone greens are still slow for a TPC course (even Jim Furyk told me they were very slow during the WGC match play). Cart path only leads to most players walking and thus prolonged playing times (5+ hours).  Even city residents have to purchase an additional golf card for $90 to get the resident rate. Compound these problems with a verrrrrryyyyshitty pro shop manager (rude and unrelenting to reservation problems (ie. see comments by others about pro shop employees)) adds to the reason why the sport of golf is dying.   I would not recommend playing here.

Avoid.
author: Robert N.

description:
Some call it the poor man's Olympic Club which is located across the lake.  Improvements over the years have made it more pricey but there are still great deals for residents and junior golfers..

The course just underwent a 4 month reconstruction of the greens and they are terrific.

The 9 hole Fleming course is good for beginning-intermediate golfers.  

Those new to Northern California golf will find the greens to be small and the fairways to be narrow compared to what you might find in the Midwest.  You won't find many cities which have as many world class golf course within its limits, and TPC Harding is one of them..
author: Erik H.

description:
There are many things in San Francisco that are resting on their historical popularity, but no longer live up to their old levels of excellence. Harding Park is in danger of becoming ne of those things. 
The Staff is great. And the course was in pretty great shape. But like earlier reviews, it's not particularly interesting. Yes the 18th is spectacular, but the other 17 could be found at a good Muni somewhere. Also, the driving range alone should get negative stars if that's possible. They have adopted the new mats that do not allow for using a rubber tee. But you can use your own tees. Probably one for each shot. The place looks like a garbage dump of old broken tees, candy wrappers, ball sleeves, etc. A real dump. And the range has been in that condition the last 3 times I was there.

Another thing is the carts. They have programmed the GPS to prohibit you from...well from doing anything they don't want you to do. For example...take the cart to your car to help you unload your clubs? Nope, sorry carts are not allowed in the parking lot. So...the cart just dies and strands you just after you cross the line into the lot. It also strands you if you are going someplace on the course it doesn't want you to go. One of our players hit a bad shot onto another fairway....and his cart stalled as he went after it. Sorry, your not supposed to be on that fairway.... It only would allow him to drive in reverse, as he backed his way onto the 'right' fairway. He uses a cart for his bad hip...but who cares about him? It's much more important that everything is under control.

Another thing that reduces the pleasure of playing Harding is the Police Gun Range adjoining the property. LOUD automatic rifle shots for our ENTIRE round. Not Harding's fault, but just another nail in the coffin.

Finally, you will see a sign that says they are changing to "Demand Pricing". I think this is ala Uber. When demand is high they raise the prices. But the best part is....they claim it is "In the interest of fairness and equity" Seriously???? Raising prices keeps things "equitable" Holy cow, if that isn't the epitome of San Francisco-think I don't know what is.

So I will enjoy Harding by going to the restaurant, and walking along Lake Merced, but I wouldn't recommend wasting your golf money on Harding. Crystal Springs is a much more interesting course.
author: william c.

description:
One of the Best Courses in the Bay Area. I will make time to play this course when ever my golfing buddies can get a decent tee time. We got a $99 rate on a Master Card TPC promotion which includes greens fees, cart. lunch and a $25 gift card for the pro shop. Great deal !!!!. 

We had a 8:18 am tee time, never saw the group in front of us or behind us. The course is in immaculate condition. The weather was cool and overcast but this is usual for Harding Park.
author: George F.

description: One of my absolute favorite courses in San Francisco. Harding park is long and tests your mental toughness. The course layout makes it look easy but boy does the second shot count on every hole... Greens are firm and fast and the pace of play is decent. Good practice area and plenty of parking. This is the easier golf course to drive to as compared to Presidio.
author: Adi R.

description:
The price keeps it from being 5 star. I think non-resident during week is about $120. Type of place to play couple times a year. One of the great walking courses.

Played yesterday. Penile rough. Yes, I said penile. Rewards hitting clearly defined fairways. Straight ahead golf, no blind shots. Lots of fun. Oddly, has a lot of dogleft left holes so be ready to work your drives or go 3-wood off the tee. 

Front gets a little repetitive with 380 and 400 yard up and back holes to  slightly elevated greens. Back provides more challenge and elevation change. Surprised slope from the 6400 white tees only 121. It was hard to hit good shots out of the rough, whereas lesser Bay Area courses you always have a shot. HInt: don't try to hit fairway woods from the rough here--just choke down on your irons and rip it out. Last hole one of the great finishing ones in Northern California.

Restaurant is nice, range is okay. Staff somewhat helpful. Challenging track, just pricey.
author: Michael S.

description: Finally got the chance to play Harding over Christmas break and I absolutely enjoyed it! I am big fan of difficult golf courses but where the superintendent and his team are also meticulous about course maintenance; Harding is both a challenging track and in pristine shape.  Course conditions are really the most important thing to my golf outings behind playing well. But I would trade shooting a great score at mediocre course conditions for an average score on a pristine track like Harding any day! My round started a little bumpy but I finished with a run of 6 pars on the back 9.  Can't wait to play Harding again!
author: Rudy C.

description:
I haven't played the course yet but I've gone to the driving range and practiced chipping and putting a number of times. What a great course in a beautiful setting with Cypress Trees all around you and a little pond. It feels like you're in Monterrey but you're in the middle of the City.

The Clubhouse has great views of the 18th hole and it's standard fare, nothing outrageously great but solid burgers, beers, breakfast but wouldn't go just for the food.
author: Spoon G.

description:
Was chipping and putting in the practice area when a buddy of mine rolled by in his car and announced that he had the first tee time and would I like to play in the first group out. 
Yeah why not as I'm a resident and can get out for $53.00. 
Not on a Tuesday morning according to K. C. EVANS the golf shop coordinator because as I was now part of a group that had reserved a tee time in advance the rate would be $63.00. Hmmm, I mentioned to the chap that the whole point of having a resident card was to get the resident rate. He responded that if one person in the group pays the $10.00 advance reservation fee then all have to pay. Okay, I said then put me on the sign up sheet as a single waiting to go out. He responded that he hadn't started one yet and was going to send out the first group as a threesome minus me!
Is this guy a jackass? Why the friction? Why the toady and argumentative behavior? 
Where is a customer service attitude that wants to penalize, cause disruption, create bad karma and generally be an asshole! Well I guess that some people just have it as a natural part of their DNA. Probably it was just as well that I did not pay as I heard similar negative comments from other golfers about this particular employee so consequently have a faint glimmer of hope that K. C. EVANS will be spending some non paid time on customer service training, learning to say please and thank you and recognizing that Idi Amin, Genghis Khan and Adolf Hitler never played golf!
author: Ian M.

description: Happy Birthday, Dad! Now both daughters playing. Omg!
author: Chris L.

description: The greens are pure, the course is long and honest. Have your A game and be rewarded with true putts. Aggressive chipping and pitching is helpful around the greens. There's trouble both left and right so, practice your long game before the first tee. One of the treasures of the Bay Area, pack an extra clothing layer and enjoy your day!
author: Steve K.

description:
Let me qualify this review by stating that I was a golf professional for 5yrs at a high end resort in Orlando.  I now play 100+ rounds a year and most USGA Qualifiers since leaving the golf industry and gaining my amateur status back.  This will be somewhat uncomfortable of a review, but lets go. 

The inside staff was very accommodating as I was playing as a guest since I am a member at another TPC property.   They allowed me to pair up and tee off early since there is no driving range open.  I went and checked in with the starter and he was great.  He paired me up while I rolled some practice putts and off we went.  

The layout was great and the scenery was amazing, there is no denying that.  Also I won't complain about the gun range or noise as this us a busy metro area and one cannot realistically expect silence in this environment.  

The greens were sooo slow it was almost a joke.  They look fantastic and they are healthy but they could not have ran more than a 6 or so on the stimp meter.  Not to mention there was a temporary green on #3 that the staff neglected to mention at check in.   For over $100 a round this was pretty comical.  

Lastly their course advisor/maintenance person John was a less than tactful individual and who more concerned with scolding me for playing the tips than keeping the groups ahead of us moving. (there were no signs or notices that the back tees were closed).  

Overall the layout and photo ops were superb, but the conditions, service, and communication need some serious work/improvement.  

If a $100+ muni is what your looking for then this is your home!  Please do not expect the same facilities, conditions, or service that you are used to at other TPC Properties. (Stonebrae, Las Vegas, Scottsdale, SanAntonio, etc)  The TPC moniker here is very misleading and in no way indicative of the experience you will have. 

Would I recommend a friend?  NO

Will I play there again?  If I had confirmation things have changed, but Im not paying that much to putt on glorified fairways again.
author: Zac F.

description: A nice well manicured golf course. Really has no signature hole. Fairways and greens are excellent. Sand traps are very good with white beach sand. The rough is thick. Keep the ball in the fairway. The staff was very pleasant. Green fees are too high and the restaurant is overpriced. I played this course because of all the publicity it has received since being renovated. It is overrated. If you can you should walk this course. Almost every one does.It is cart path only all the way around. Torrey Pines North is a comparable course. Also overpriced and somewhat overrated.
author: Jeff P.

description: For my boyfriend's birthday I got him golf rounds at 3 different bay area courses. While this one was his 3rd favorite, it was still a very nice course. We found it to be well maintained with pretty scenery and nice staff. There wasn't anything that really made it unique, the course was similar to any municipal course, except that it had a prettier than typical setting. They were nice enough to give us the bay area rate because they had just aerated the greens.
author: Aj S.

description:
Got here @ 6a 
Didn't have a time 
Chris & staff tried to get me out 
But were unsuccessful 
Looks like a beautiful track 
& the girl behind the counter 
Shud try modeling besides standing behind counter.. jus saying 
Till next time harding park!
author: Thinh D.

description:
Played here 2 weeks after the WGC match play when pricing was still a little higher (due to better course conditions?)  The course is a fun track and can be a test from the blue tees but what was most disappointing were the greens which were smooth but slower than molasses and had a lot of pitch marks that had not been replaced.  Fairways were good, rough was punitive but not impossible and a couple of bunkers could have stood a little more sand in them.
Overall the course is fun to play and as mentioned before a pretty good test for all levels of golfer.
author: Mike D.

description:
Fantastic!  Played on Sunday 10/9 with a 9:30am tee time.  The day was perfect!  October is the best time for SF golf, people don't usually realize that.  Although the course was busy we never had much of a wait, when we hit the turn we took a little longer then we should have and got a hole behind the group in front.  Even though they group behind us was not close the marshall asked us to catch up.  A marshall who actually does his job????  Loved it! (and yes we caught up).
Conditions were excellent even though we are in a drought.  The rough was short and the greens a little slow but as it was described to us, lightning greens and long rough cause slow play and are actually not good for the course conditions.
The food was very good as well, got a dog and chips at the turn and they were also grilling burgers and brats.  Not cheap, but it IS San Francisco after all.
Will play again... FYI if you can play 2 courses play Presidio as well!
author: Walt B.

description:
TPC Harding Park is an absolute gem of a course to play golf. It's hands down my favorite course to play in the Bay.

Location: The course is located just south of the City, so it's a great place for both tourists and locals. I live in the south Bay, so it takes me a while to get up there, but in my opinion, it's worth it. Also, I obviously don't have to go clear into the city.

Clubhouse: The clubhouse is very nice; at the higher end of clubhouses around. The restaurant is good for a bite, they have free WiFi, and the pro shop is stocked with good merchandise if you need to take a TPC Harding Park souvenir home. Prices are okay for a TPC clubhouse...felt about on par.

Driving Range: The range leaves something to be desired, but I think the course itself makes up for it and then some. The range is mats, it's small, and it's not very deep. I would probably just plan on hitting a small bucket of irons before your round, but hey you do what you gotta do.

Course: The course is spectacular. It's layout is really built for walking. Let me be clear that I much prefer, and almost always do, ride versus walk. However, the course layout, and the fact that it's cart path only, kind of makes your understand why the majority of folks walk. There are definitely carts available, and if someone like my dad comes to play, we definitely grab a car. In general, though, if you've thought it might be fun to walk a course, this is the one. The fairways and greens are beautiful, and the scenery is so good. 

Price: Harding Park is definitely not cheap, but it's also a pretty good deal for being just south of the City and in the Bay Area as a TPC course. Plus, to give you an idea of how good the course is, the US Open and President's Cup are being played there in the coming years. That's just sick nasty. I typically get there for twilight as it's a bit more affordable, and I get another break being a Bay Area County resident. The SF city residents get the prime price reduction...lucky dogs!

Go here...but don't go too much because I still need to get my tee times. Thanks.
author: Paul B.

description:
I hate paying to get punished, but I see it a lot here in Harding Park.  People punished by the weather.  Punished by cart path only.  Punished by the tough course.  Punished by the high price (unless you possess a San Francisco resident card.

For me, it's not a punishment.  I prefer to walk this course, save a few bucks, and re-live the same experience Tiger Woods and John Daly had at the American Express tournament, except that I hit about 20 strokes higher.  Nice old cypress trees line the fairway, and strategically placed bunkers guard most of the holes.  Surprisingly, the greens were hard (not difficult hard, but bounce hard) and it did not match the sogginess of some of the fairway.

With only three public golf courses in San Francisco, TPC Harding Park got you by the balls.
author: Ron L.

description:
We stopped by this golf course and encountered some rude, racist staff in the store. They would practically stared at you as if they think you will steal their junks. Looser place looser staff.
They dont make me feel welcome to return. Are they stuck up now because they are TPC?
No wonder why a lot of people are leaving the game. Dealing with stuck up racists can ruin your vacation.
author: Lulu L.

description: Greens have been slow in prep for the WGC. Keep your eye on the ball into the rough, even though it's not that long the ball sits down and hides easily. Great track
author: Paul P.

description: Such a close drive, and now a memorable moment,  at the Cadillac match play event with @r_dub_flo and we both almost gets hit with @rorymcilroy 12 hole shot vs Jim.  Great times!!!
author: Richard G.

description: First day of Cadillac Match Play @tpcharding @WGC_MatchPlay Awesome set up with lots of great golf goodies
author: Bubba M.

description: Awful place. Very rude staff. Badly behaved people.  Low quality club. Only good for losers who try to look pretty by going to a "golf club"
author: Carlo T.

description: As a native I enjoy coming here for many reasons but I was disappointed this past weekend to find out that they had taken the Eggs Benedict off the menu. Whyyyyyyyyy!?!?!
author: Manuel M.

description: I played Fleming for the first time in a while two weeks ago and I was blown away by the conditions. You would never know that it has been raining so much. Tee boxes and fairways were nicely mowed and well kept. The greens were pure and were rolling super fast! My only complaint is that there should be a marshal out on Fleming as the pace of play was very slow, we waited on every shot on every hole. I feel that some of the holes could be shortened, maybe another set of tees for beginners, juniors and seniors. Overall a fun track. I look forward to many more rounds here in the future.
author: Joe K.

description:
I've played this course dozens of times, both before and since the acquisition by TPC, and I have to say, it continues to amaze me. My most recent visit this past Monday (Memorial Day) only served the solidify that opinion.

The course is beautiful and well-kept, and the greens and bunkers have been vastly improved by the recent restoration. The bunkers are now full of pristine, fine, white sand (compared to the inconsistent, clumpier sand in the old ones), and their lips are much cleaner and not collapsed like so many of the old ones were. The greens, while somewhat slow due to how recently they opened, roll true, and again, are much more consistent than their poa annua infected predecessors (let's hope that doesn't happen again!). I was reminded of Harding's natural beauty when I played on Monday. The back nine truly is a treat, meandering around the inner front nine and showcasing beautiful views of San Francisco, The Olympic Club, and Lake Merced as you progress through it. 

The course is forgiving for those who spray it, making it (unfortunately) somewhat of a hacker's paradise, but it is by no means easy. Both birdies and lost balls are few and far between; the length and subtleties of the course make up for its forgiving nature. The course culminates with arguably one of the best 18th holes in golf: a long, dogleg left par-4 with Lake Merced on the left and bunkers to the right. A draw isn't necessary to hit the fairway, but shaping one around the corner makes the hole significantly easier. The green is tiered and domed, with bunkers swallowing shots to the left, and gives me fits each time I play the hole, but it doesn't mean I love it any less. It's a perfect finish to a great course, and a challenge I always look forward to. 

The Cypress Grill is great, too. The waiters and waitresses are nice, and the food is solid. I always order the chili, which is delicious. Most of the people in the Pro Shop are polite and helpful, and will try and help you when they can. It's also very organized. If you have a tee time, you'll almost always get out on time, and if you don't, you will either be given a time, or asked for your phone number, put on a wait list, and called when there is a time available, which is great. 

A few cons: first, it can be pricey. I was lucky enough to have been able to get the junior rate for many years, which was $15 M-F and $21 on weekends and holidays. That was a deal! Now that I am no longer a junior, the rates have jumped, but that's a theme for most courses. Harding is especially expensive if you're not from the Bay Area/SF. Another con is the range. It was recently outfitted with new mats, but I liken that to trying to fix a bullet wound with a band-aid; it's just not going to work. For the money you're paying, Harding should have a grass range. The chipping and putting greens are good, however, so that's a bonus. 

Overall, Harding is a great course and experience. If you're from out of town and have the money to spend, do it. You won't regret it.
author: Zander N.

description:
I was so surprised by the horrendous attitudes of those two stupid staffs at the pro shop, especially the one with dark skin called KC EVANS.
First he ridiculously assumed I had zero experience on golf and kept telling me this club worths $200 and this course costs $150+ to play. I have no idea where this judgment came from.  I was laughing so loud in my stomach - I played golf 100+ round a year within 7 handicap. I just wanted to play with him see how he could carry on his stupid attitude. There is a couple other racist gestures and talks I really don't feel comfortable and don't even bother to type in. On the other hand, I still don't get it how come a guy worked in a golf shop for living carrying such huge pride - good for him.

I read the reviews on yelp - not so surprised I found I'm not the only one who had similar experience. TPC was a big brand in my mind. I just can't believe how they could let such a racist idiot jeopardize their reputations.
Truly unbelievable and offensive experience.
author: Alex Z.

description: I was ringing to see if I could book a tee time for today Monday 25th. I was placed on hold by Melissa for ten minutes, hung up rang back and Melissa answered the phone again this time no hold.. I told her I was waiting for ten mins, no apology just asked what I needed... Bit rude.. Anyway asked if I could book tee time for the afternoon, she said same day bookings were not available, I asked about the online booking she said in a deeper tone same day booking were not allowed.. I prefer to book over the phone directly. Did the online thing and booked for the same day... Read a few reviews and arrogance and the feeling of they think they are better than everyone else because they got a few tournaments seem to trending... Anyway nice course bit pricey if you don't have a residents card 4* for the course,but the exchange with Melissa -3*... Work on yer customer service 1*
author: stevie h.

description: Ok, the course it self is amazing. That said it's a bid disappointment in any other area. condition was below average. Price was 175 with a yardage book and cart. range balls are 35 for 7 and up from there. food and bev are outrageous even for here. gyro was 17. And it sucked. Hot Dog was 9 with chips and drink and it was good. As packed a course as you will ever see. Non-stop play leaves the course unable to recover. the greens were as long as Chrystal Gail's hair in 1979! rolling about an 8 or less even. Wow, not very TPC. The staff was nice but, rotten at their jobs. The fairways are soupy. The whole thing is pretty disappointing really. I'll never play another TPC again. Do yourself a favor and head to some courses north and day trip it down if you absolutely must but, if you think your gonna play a nice course here you are dead wrong. What they have is an amazing piece of ground that has nearly unacceptable conditions and a staff that is super nice and not that into the job. I can see why.
author: Albert M.

description:
This is for the clubhouse restaurant: 

The food was 4 stars it was a great breakfast. Had french toast where the bread was dipped in egg whites only, had strawberries and walnuts on top, I asked for whipped cream and they added that on top. Very delicious. 

Service... 2 stars, I couldn't get anyone to set a table and it wasn't that busy... but they weren't prepared for the holiday crowd. Finally whipping down the table myself our server Rhea came up and took the towel away and I guess had to do it herself (even though she was too busy before and told us to sit at a different table). Then we took the wrapped napkin silverware over to the table and she goes... no.... leave that there, and takes a different setting from the bin over. Not sure how it makes a difference if she brings over new flatware to the new table or old. Nonetheless when we thanked her she had a very unpleasant attitude. I've worked restaurant so I can understand her frustration... but when you're working, leave it at home and give the patrons a nice experience. We had to look beyond her less than pleasant attitude to enjoy our breakfast.
author: Kimberly W.

description:
I really don't know how my playing partners and I survived the blistering 25 mph gushes of wind this Sunday afternoon.  It's the windiest I've ever seen Harding Park.  At one point my hat was blown off my head and rolled half way down a long fairway.  It was definitely one of those Bill Murray Caddy Shack moments, that if it was videotaped, would have made me look ridiculous and foolish.  Despite the crazy wind conditions today, my friends and I still managed to post decent numbers, although we had major problems in the last three holes which ballooned our scores from good to average.

HPGC always plays well but today had incredibly slow greens.  It was unexpected but welcomed since Mother Nature didn't want to cooperate today.  The greens, I've always felt, were faster.

Special thanks should be given to the guys at the pro shop.  They're always cool!  It's a shame that a lot of the good ones have left or are leaving soon.  Take it easy guys!
author: Jules S.

description: We started off with an early 7:00 AM tee time. It was a little wet out, but it cleared up quickly. Parking is plentiful a and the staff is friendly. The greens are well manicured with a lot of tree shading. This is a good deal if you are a resident of San Francisco.
author: Charles B.

description: Course was pretty cool. Fun track and a easy walk. HOWEVER, the greens were a serious disappointment, crazy slow, bumpy, and unfixed divots everywhere. As a TPC course I would have thought that green maintenance would be a priority but apparently not here.
author: Eric N.

description: I am a regular there but haven't played for a few weeks.  Hopped on the course yesterday afternoon.  To my amazement the course was in terrible condition.  There is grass growing in many of the bunkers.  The fairways look and play like Omaha Beach on D-Day.  Un-filled divots everywhere. Weeds growing everywhere.  The tee boxes wer shaggy and feels like they haven't been cut for days.  When I asked the starter at the turn (his name was Malcolm) whats going on with the course?  Its in terrible shape.. his answer was, ".....that's your opinion....".  Wow,  that's TPC Harding's attitude now?  Charge the players and arm and a leg and give them crap to play on.  I can't say I'll be back anytime soon.  I'll stick to the Presidio.  Just a warning for everyone...
author: Neal H.

description:
I have been playing Harding on pretty much a weekly basis.  Although the course does not necessarily fit my eye.  It is an excellent test of golf.  After a rather plain front nine, the course really ramps up for a great back 9 finish.  Starting with the approach to 13, the final 6 holes are a lot of fun to play.

The greens have always been on the rather slow side, with the new renovation of the greens and bunkers in early 2014, the course is looking up.
author: Patrick K.

description:
My friends and I enjoy playing the 9 hole course.  The course is wide and flat.  It's a par 3 with the exception of 3 par 4's.  

As much as we enjoy the course, I've got a couple of pet peeves- the First Tee summer program is in full swing (no pun intended), and the course backs up in the morning around 9'ish.  Then you've got to wait.  A couple of weeks ago we waited at the 1st hole for about 30-45 minutes.  Today we arrived around 10:30a.m. and the pro shop informed us that it was going to be slow.  And the green fees for a 9 hole of $21.00 is steep.  Yes with a resident card.  We thanked him for the heads up and decided to play.  Hip hip hoorah.  It wasn't too bad.

My 2nd peeve - after a major event like the Schwab, Fleming looks beat up.  The greens are trampled and the bunkers are even worse.

Other than those two pet peeves, it's a great course and right in the neighborhood.
author: Shirley N.

description: That young fella Ned in the pro shop is so nice and attentive. He makes me feel like TPC Harding is my home away from home. I will always come back here, as long as employees with the customer service skills like Ned are around. See you soon TPC!
author: Mike H.

description: Great course for the locals. An easy course to walk and everybody does; you can get a cart but it's cart path only. Pace of play is usually decent since everybody is walking but it's never great unless you go out early. There is a decent but small chipping/putting area and a large practice putting (only) green. The driving range is mats and terrible balls but a good way to warm up before a round.
author: Garret R.

description: Good course, but god it was in bad shape. For a golf course that charges you over 70 dollars after 4 o'clock on weekdays, the greens are just a joke. So slow and did not roll true or pure. Every putt I had wobbled and was bumping. Very frustrating when you pay that much and have to putt on fairways. Course is in decent shape, I can tell the staff is kind of letting it go. For a "TPC" golf course, I definitely expected way better. Play was slow, a surprising amount of guys playing in jeans and a t shirt. Overall quite disappointed in this course because of the pedigree of tournament's that have been held here. For all the hype and the great tournaments that have been held here, they are really letting it go and will have to scramble to get it back come tournament time.
author: Jay M.

description:
For city residents with the discount card this could be a 3.5/4, for NorCal residents (which I am) it's a 3, for out of towners paying the full whack, it's more a 2.5. The price differences are so great between the three it has a serious impact on the rating and value of the course.

I really like the traditional feel of the place, the sighting of the greens and next tee boxes, the natural movement to the slopes and elevation changes. As others note the closing stretch along the lake is top drawer stuff and 18 is a serious finishing hole.

That said, there is a sense of sameness to some of the middle holes as you play back and forth through the centre of the property. Also the greens were bumpy as the different grasses fought each other for prominence. Then there is the price. This is not a $100+ course, we played twilight at $79 and felt that was stretching it. Half Moon Bay Ocean Course and Wente are the local benchmarks for $80 rounds and TPC Harding Park falls short.
author: Pints 'n Putt S.

description:
It's such a shame. This used to be such a wonderful course until TPC took it over. The course itself still plays beautifully, especially after the renovation
However, this organization is not about the player experience, it is about money. If you call to walk on, they will tell you to "come on out and they will get you out there". Expect a 2 to 3 hour wait at minimum.  
And then you will be playing a four and a half to five hour round, waiting behind all the other densely packed golfers. 
If you have all the time in the world, and don't mind slapping down moderate sums of coin, then play it. It's a good course. 
They have just wasted too much if my precious time and too many other great courses nearby.
author: Paul E.

description: What a beautiful golf course!!! It is too bad that you get treated like you do not belong there at the front counter like its a country club. Do not be mistaken TPC this is still a very public course. I have been here probably 20-30 times and without fail there is always a problem getting out as a single! You can hit puts and watch as the tee box sits empty because nobody plays here because of the price and the service. I have no problem paying the $100 green fee but I feel like you should get some kind of decent experience from the car to the first tee. I hate to say it but I will continue to play this course despite the lack of courtesy at the front counter because the course is so good.
author: Sean C.

description: I've been golfing here for well over a year as it is the closest course and it is very well kept and the staff is friendly. Even the adjacent 9 hole course, called Fleming, is a nice experience. The grass and greens are almost always perfect no matter what the weather is like. The dense fog that rolls in over the lake gives a nice atmosphere for your golf shots. It is so serene here that on some holes you can hear your golf ball whistle as it's rips through the fog, spinning and whipping across the fairway. I have played a lot of courses around the world and this one is genuinely world class. One if the best courses I have ever played on.
author: peter w.

description:
As an SF Resident I delight in the resident discount.  Courses are maintained nicely, carts are always available and golfers are generally friendly and we've had numerous occasions of golfers joining our game, which add to the enjoyment.  

The clubhouse also has a great view and make for an entertaining lunch or quick stop for a drink.  The staff are also very friendly and spend the time to get to know you by name.  Good food, reasonably priced.
author: ERICA G.

description:
this is someone who use to play the old harding back in the early 2000s and 90s.. First if you have a resident card it saves you half the cost.. you pay 46 compared to 90 or 100plus..

Course9 :Very wide open .. Cypress trees surround the course.. There are all sorts of holes out here.. Not that many blind shots. 

Length: 9 Most the holes from the whites are over 350 yards. The par 3's take a 6 iron or up... number 10 is a easy 2 shot hole for the pros but  a 3 shot par 3 for the average golfer.. 

Holes:8 :   Some of my favorite is the 4th hole dogleg right par five.. 3 shot hole into a well protected green.. I like hole 7 a short par 4 but I sill always mange to  double bogy because its well guarded by bunkers and has elevated green.  Number 9 is fun.. a straight par 5... Background 9 is designed on the outter part of the course and lake merced. Number 11 is a average par 3 that you aim at SFSU building. Hole 12 is famous for all the golf balls on the fence that are stuck because of people who have that power fade. Hole 14 is a pretty hole.. Now hole 18 OMG is long.... Your drive is over a part of the lake.. But the second shot is to an elevated green that use to be the old putting green. So for me its like driver, 3 wood, and wedge.. 

Bunker: 10 .. Hit in the bunkers is like sitting on Carmel Beaches..

Fairways: 9 super nice except when its fogy

Service: 9... you can book ahead .. or show up. Actually one time I ordered lunch but had to tee off. They brought me my food and didnt charge me. nice people.

Fun Factor:; Honestly the course isnt worth 100 bucks to play.. its not memorable like the San Diego Course or Bethpage Black..But it is wide open course and does challenge you..
author: Scotty L.

description:
Wow, what a day that was.  It's one of these days I'll never forget in my life, getting a chance to play at this course that is an TPC course.  A golfer's dream.  TPC is The Players' Championships where PGA tour players compete on.  My mentor and I played at this course one WEEK before the Champion Tour event, which Fred Couples would win.  I could see yard crewsmen working on the course and even one guy stopped sprinkling water and stood aside as I was working my ball that lie near the sand bunker.

I got a little lucky getting a tee's time here as I took Friday off and treated my mentor because he was the one who got me started on the game of golf when I was young.  It would be our first time playing here.  I got off to a bad start as I made a bogey on the first hole, then a double bogey on the next hole because my ball got into a sand bunker and my ball hit the edge of the bunker and stayed in the bunker again!  I was pissed, but was able to settle down and started to make par, a birdie, and ended up with a decent score, which was 82.

It's a classic course with lots of cypress trees, fairways kept clean and nice, and as you progress along, the last 5 holes are close to the water, so you will have to keep your swing in check.  I did and did not lose a single ball.  Will try to play again!
author: Nathan K.

description:
This course just gets better every time I play here.  Even though sometimes it can be super cold and windy, when it's not, it's pure golf heaven.  Wide open fairways,  well-maintained greens and tee boxes...it has it all in a beautiful San Francisco setting.  It's a total shame that the shooting range is nearby because on some holes it's too loud to be avoidable.

But today was fantastic.  It wasn't too crowded, so pace of play was good, it wasn't even too soggy from our rain, and we just enjoyed the day.

On an aside, kudos to the guy at the ProShop who suggested a "cadet" glove since I always seem to lose the stitching on the outer part of all my gloves....the FJ glove he recommended is not only incredibly comfy, it fits...well...like a glove.
author: Tamar D.

description:
Without a doubt the best course in all of San Francisco (aside from snooty private courses I can't seem to make my way into).

The course is kept in immaculate condition. Fairways are great and clean. Not a lot of divots or bad patches of grass everywhere. Greens are in great condition and very fast. It's like putting on concrete.

The cypress trees all over the place make it a beautiful walk the entire time. And let's not get started with that 18th hole. What a great view and play.

The Cypress Grill is nice too. $9 for a huge huevos rancheros with a fist full of carnitas on top? Don't mind if I do!

One other little cool thing is the air compressor at the club house. I love those things. It blows air to get all the grass and gunk off my golf shoes! Score! I love you, little air compressor air blowy thingie that keeps my golf shoes perfect!

The only bad thing about this course is it is cart path only. If you take golf carts, you will end up walking more than if you just decided to walk the course. Cart path only is nice in that the course itself stays in better shape. Just get a pull cart or walk it. The course is absolutely amazing and is worth it.

Expensive, but just get your SF golf card and then it's the best deal in town. After playing here, I'm going to get my golf card and will work a few hours overtime every week and am gonna make this course my own little happy place.
author: Ryan E.

description:
I'm proud to call Fleming my home course.  It's well maintained, picturesque and players are friendly.  Even the food at the clubhouse is good.  Being flat and wide, the course's biggest challenge is...trees!  The cypress branches extend over the fairways clipping shots short and returning balls in every direction.  I can't remember a round without someone in our group hitting a tree.  

A cypress gobbled up my husband's ball once - here are your options if it happens to you:
1.  Climb in to tree and play the ball - unlikely with these cypresses
2.  If you can see the ball from the ground, take a drop with penalty stroke
3.  If you can't see the ball at all play lost ball rules

The only negative thing about Fleming is that there are a lot of really slow beginners.  A little slow play on nine holes is expected but the last time we played in the afternoon a foursome took almost 40 minutes to play each hole. It looked like one person was giving everyone lessons on the course and they even let three groups play through.  Since then, we only play first thing in the morning so we can get off the course in two hours.  As a bonus, the driving range isn't active at that hour either.  Lesson learned!
author: Aileen N.

description: Best value for a high-end public course out there.
author: Travis R.

description: I play golf there at least once a week with the First Tee of San Francisco. Golf is really fun, calm, and enjoyable. A little more about First Tee is that they, gave me opportunities to do cool things. Especially playing golf with my friends. If u have a son or daughter who may take an interest in golf, send them in to the First Tee and good place to learn and have fun.
author: Justin D.

description: I used to play here a bunch when I had the coveted city resident card. Now, living in Alameda, I have pretty good choices at good rates close by so haven't been to Harding in a few years. A friend was visiting and I wanted to show him a good time. He plays a lot of golf at top courses and I didn't want to take him just anywhere. Even though it was more than I was used to paying, the experience here was worth it! The new greens were beautiful (though still slow, aim at the cup and hit it!) and the rest of the course was lush and immaculate. We had a blast! And the service was wonderful too. My buddy thought it was definitely a better course than SF CC and is looking forward to coming back soon. If I could only get a resident card somehow...
author: Spencer B.

description:
I just played Harding Park GC this week after not playing it for 2 years.  I love it.  It is an excellent course that provides a very good challenge, and since TPC has taken over it is very well maintained.  Each time I go out to play Harding, I always say to myself, "This is not that tough of a course.  I should score well!"  Each time I come away from the course shaking my head saying..."How did I do so badly?" It is a deceptively tough course.  Maybe, because it plays longer than what's on the scorecard.  

Maybe, because the greens roll faster than you think.  Maybe, maybe, maybe...one thing for sure, it is a very enjoyable course.  It is walkable and you should probably walk anyway, since it's cart path only throughout.

Finally, I'd add...for non-residents, it is overpriced.  I think they're charging something like $150 to play it.  It's a great course but not worth $150 bucks!
author: Ed G.

description:
Over priced and way out of line for serveral reasons  1.  The food selection is weak 2. the Entire golf course is Cart path only everyday of the week 3.  there really are no great views of the city. 4.  Ist not worth the price.     Cache Creek  is a much better value if your going to spend that kind of money and to me a much better course and the service and food is outstanding.  Lincoln park is a lot more affordable at 25 dollars and it may not be the best or the longest but its got some of the  best San Francisco views hands down of any golf course in the city its a little hillly but fun and you don't have to spend all your vacation money to play golf.  the only reason I play harding is because I get a resident discount because I live in the city   and since they went up on there price
I don't even play there anymore   harding is over priced I don't care if the us open is played there every year  when they are not there the bottom line is for the public to enjoy the course and at those prices its really hard to play there   that's why they get a rating of 1 star   from me
author: Ricky R.

description:
I've been to Harding twice, once to play and the other to watch Tiger win a tournament. It is a great muni course, so great that the PGA has used it twice for tournaments in the last four years.

When I played here, I was shocked to see such a low course rating and slope. I played the tips to give myself a chance for a good differential, and that was a huge mistake. The trees absolutely feasted on my balls. I played poorly, the course ate me up, I got discouraged... I moved up to the white tees by about the 8th hole because I needed mouth-to-mouth resuscitation. My game was dying.

A great place to play, totally disregard the CR and Slope because they are bogus. Don't get all macho and move to the blues. I've seen this place eat up the best of the best.
author: Joel V.

description: After the Stephan Curry Golf Tournament our Nephews Bose Mini Speaker and iPod were left in the cart. He called and reported the loss.  A day later the speaker and iPod were found and turned in!! That was the best news!!! The person that turned it in should be rewarded for honesty and integrity. There is always Hope!!!! Thank you Harding Park!!
author: Wendy A M.

description:
The cost to play this public course is way out of line for what you get. We played a tournament on a Sunday, so it was not mid week or an off day. First off, no carts on the fairways, which were dry. This made for a slow pace of play and a long round.
  The marshal was an ass, just barking orders without any idea of the big picture. No food service at the walk up window at the turn. WTF? This was a weekend with the course full.... Had to go into the grille, as per the posted sign for food. Only two prepared sandwiches, Turkey and Tuna for $8.00. Crappy selection and way the hell over priced.
  The greens were horrible. They had not been groomed in days and were very, very slow. Not at all what you would expect from a so called TPC venue. We came to the conclusion that they hadn't mowed the greens as plugging was due to start the following week. So what about all the players that ponied up the $135 plus for the green fees? Didn't we deserve a better surface based on the money charged?
   I will not go back. There are many, many public courses in the Bay Area just as well maintained for one third of the cost to play.
author: David L.

description: This course is VERY mediocre, and very expensive, even for Bay Area residents. The design is nothing to write home about, the conditions are just average, and the greens are usually slow and hard to putt on. The range is all mats and one of the worst ones for a course of this reputation. The closing hole is the only saving grace, nice dog-leg left with a forced carry from the tee box and an uphill approach to a tilted green. This would be wll worth it if the price was $50 but $150 is a little much.
author: Pat T.

description: The last time I played here (about 2 yrs ago) the Marshall's were so rude, and wrong (they kept telling us to hurry up, even tho we were WELL ahead of our projected time) I vowed not to play here until they made a change. Reading the reviews, it appears nothing has changed. If you're from out of town, and pay $140, and are harassed by asshole Marshall's, I mean, what else is there to say? I mean, who runs this place?
author: Matthew K.

description:
Nice course and we had a good round! 

But be aware that at least one employee is a theft! 

I rent a Callaway set for a visitor from other country, also brought my spare set for another guest. There was one Callaway Mack Daddy wedge in my spare set, and I found it's disappeared recently. Obviously my guest has mixed it with the rental set and returned to Harding Park, as I never touch that set after that game. I called Harding Park and the guy said they never had a Mack Daddy returned. Well, some one took it home!

I've played around the bay area for years and dropped clubs several times, but that's the first time I really lost a club, that shouldn't happen in TPC Harding Park, their employees should be more educated.
author: Patrick C.

description: Great course and layout.  Lots of fun.  I wish the greens were faster.  Seems like I has to aim about 4-6 feet past hole to get speed right.  Still a great time and memorable experience.
author: Aaron V.

description:
A course that is sneaky tough, subtly beautiful and generally in good shape.  Sometimes the greens can be a little iffy.  One complaint as an out-of-towner is they keep raising the rates ($160 is a little steep, this is a nice course but not quite worth that rate in my opinion).

However, it's always cool to play where the pros have -- if for nothing else than to realize how much better they are than the rest of us.  Hey, Tiger hit driver, wedge here and made a birdie...i hit driver, 5 iron, chip, chip and then 3-putted!  How inspiring.
author: Jon M.

description:
My best description of this course is "Olympic Club Lite." It is a nice course that will give you a taste of what it is like to play the the storied Olympic Club: fairways lined by cypress trees, long par 4s, views of Lake Merced, etc. But make no mistake, this is NOT the Olympic Club. It feels like something between a municipal and a country club. The course overall is in pretty good shape, the roughs are not long, and with the exception of the water on 18 and the holes the line the edges of the property (think out of bounds), lost balls are a rare occurrence. The greens are pretty slow, typical of a city course, but they are going to be redone at the end of the year. 

The course itself offers a good variety of holes and could be very difficult of the rough was longer. As a San Francisco resident with a Resident Golf Card, I'm able to play here for $52 during the week and at that price it is a great deal. A real bonus is the ability walk onto the course. Just show up at the pro shop (you can't call ahead), get your name on the list, and if during the week you'll likely be on the first tee within an hour. For the out-of-towners, the $155-175 rates are likely not worth it: you can find a better deal in the Bay Area.
author: Tom H.

description:
this is a great track. Lots of good golf.

Pros
layout
challenging
great views
history

cons
course conditions are iffy (very wet)
weather can be an issue (fog)


I rate this as a must play because of the history and the course and attention it has received.
author: Stephen R.

description: Not worth the money if you are a nonresident. Golf carts are restricted to the path only and I was told that was a rule and not just the day I played. Driving range was not open due to a tear in the netting and has been for some time. The greens were absolutely terrible, it was like putting on shag carpet. Fairways were full of big divots. I've played many golf courses and will not play there again. The one plus is the golf staff was very friendly.
author: Don D.

description: Just played today with the SF Resident rate.  It is definitely worth it.  We played at a good pace and there was no one in front or behind us, for Veteran's Day, it is very rare. Today was cart path only, so it is good to just pull a walking cart. The ruff is a little bit long today, but the greens and fairways were in great condition. It was a great day to be playing golf.
author: James W.

description:
I have been a frequent visitor of TPC Harding Park and I can say without a doubt it is a fabulous place to go.  Yes it is a muni course so it will not be perfect but it is pretty darn close.  Having someone meet you out front is a hit or miss but when they are there the service is great.  Jason in the shop did a wonderful job making our check in nice and smooth.  Ive had others check us in that aren't that nice but that happens...  I think the price is a little steep for a non res and they really need a bay area card not just SF.  We did have a small problem one weekend but it was taken care of very quickly by the GM, he was extremely helpful.  We have eaten here several times and the food is amazing, great tuna melt :)

I highly reccomend trying TPC harding park.  Once the TPC took over it has only gone up hill.  It was in really bad shape before so I am ecstatic how much it has improved.  All of you that complain remember it is a muni course and it is ran by the city...  so that means union, city regs, etc...
author: Debbie J.

description: I was so excited to get out and play TPC Harding Park but I left feeling a bit disappointed. I shot 81 from the blue tees in a cold, overcast, classic SF style afternoon. Coming from SJ I had to pay $100 for my round. I felt the greens were slow and not much of a challenge once you reached them. A great course layout though, I love cypress trees. Some fairways were tough to hit and provided a great challenge off the tee. An annoying gun range close by really took away from the serenity of the beautiful course. Harding Park has the worst driving range I've ever seen for such a legit course, decent chipping/putting areas. It is a very pleasant course to walk. I'm glad I played there once but for $100 I prefer Bayonet/Black Horse, Poppy Hills or Wente Vineyards.
author: Austin J.

description: We played the 9-hole course.  The layout is a narrow and very short.  Only 2 par 4's and the rest were par 3's.  If you end up playing here, go early in the morning as it gets VERY busy after 10AM.  First come, first serve.  Not a bad place and price, considering how expensive golfing in SF can be.
author: Jeffrey S.

description: I'm a fan of the 9 hole Fleming course - even at non-resident rates, it's not as astronomically pricey as Harding is.  You can hit driver on a couple holes and it's a pleasant walk.  The layout is interesting, for the most part, though there are a couple holes that are nothing special.  Cypress trees can come into play, course is well-maintained, and it's not difficult to get on.  It's like a mini version of Harding.
author: Logan T.

description: Sad to see how arrogant they have gotten. They think they are the best now because they will be hosting the president's cup, WGC match play and the PGA championship. One marshalseem to expect you to play a 3 1/2 round. He was very rude. We were playing, we had a 9:00 tee time and it was around 12:30 when we were on the 14th hole. We were taking our time playing, just enjoying a day on the course because there was nobody behind us. All of a sudden the marshal walks up to us and says we are out of position because the group in front was already on the next green. We played 14 holes in 3 and a half hours and we're out of position? He was nothing more than a huge asshole. I tried to explain that we had a few lost balls so we were looking for them, and he barked at me that the group in front probably had the same amount of time looking for balls. What the hell is this guy talking about? The course itself is still awesome, and I enjoy playing it, but how disrespectful some of the staff here is awful, definitely lost a star from me.
author: Shawn I.

description:
Did the 18 hole. Awesome, beautiful, and pristine golf course. 

It's a lot flat ground though. Pro side is that you don't have to worry about losing a lot of balls. I played horrible that day, slicing it badly. Only lost 1 ball and probably could've found that one too. 

I would love to play it more often once I get a resident card for the discounts.
author: Ray J.

description:
Finally I get to use my SF Golf Card...Yay!...Cholo was more excited for me...he was already lining up..Lincoln...Golden Gate...he wants me to get out there and really feel how it is being on the fairway.

So okay, this is the 2nd 9hole course I have played at and its definitely much better than Cypress...(sorry Cypress).

Guy at the counter was extremely nice to me, esp with my 1thousand question and like always Cholo was just shaking his head, smiling from ear to ear.

I dont have a golf cart yet, so Cholo lent me his and he rented one that he will use, the one he calls "dorky" because of their huge wheels...lol.

Now, I feel more like a Golfer (not yet that great but hoping to get there), the scenery is definetly much better and you can smell the grass.

I have triple bogeys but who cares and besides this this is just the 2nd week that from I started, Cholo keeps saying that I am his best student by far...hmmm...since I get it and I listen to his coaching...(thanks).

We will definitely come back and soon.
author: Malou C.

description:
You remember last Sunday?  When it was raining sheets, and cold, and windy?  What did you do that day?  Stay in, make hot chocolate, watch TV?  Ninny.  What did I do?  My brother and I played a round at Harding.  Why?  Because (1) we had a tee time, (2) he's getting deployed again sometime soon, (3) we're real men.

I filled a Mulholland Bros. flask full of Bullit to sustain us through our round.  He wore a pair of yellow rain pants he'd bought a few months ago, I wore a yellow rain pullover that I bought over a decade ago.  It had been over a year since I played, and I still hit the occasional shot.  But I was the perpetual low man on the totem pole, because I got to watch my brother, in weather conditions that would make an Alaskan crab fisherman proud, make the turn at Harding 3 over.  Seldom does my brother get the chance to school me at this particular game, and seldom do I enjoy watching someone kick my butt, but this day was different.

And so, for the few months that he gets to spend in the Great Big Bunker, living in a tent---the same few months that it looks like I will spend working 16-hour days and trying to set right that which once went wrong---we'll both get to look back on one wet and cold day in SF, where for a brief minute, my brother posted a score that would stand him in good stead in any tournament ever held at Harding.  Odd that a memory of a cold day can make one warm in reflection.  Or maybe not that odd.
author: Ben P.

description: For wedding planners: if you're planning a wedding ceremony here, you should really reconsider. A shooting range is right next door and is very disruptive!!! Can you imagine exchanging your vows with a series of gun fire sounding out. I was here for a wedding it was pretty awful. The place is very pretty and parking is plentiful... but the background noise is just not very romantic.
author: Anne T.

description:
Just an update as I just finished another round on this great course.

I'm not sure if it was the slightly drier conditions or the attention the course is getting from the PGA staffed greens keeping crew but I was surprised at how much better the course is looking and playing from a mere few weeks ago.

So here's the updates. Morning round, approx. 60 degree weather with clouds overhead.

Tee Box: same report as before. Flat and firm.

Fairways: Firm, cut tight, rolling fast. Noticed that they sand the fairways now on most of the holes.

Bunkers: Fluffy sand now. Not the sandbox sand that feels like you're hitting into pebbles.

Rough: You can actually see the difference btwn the first cut and second cut now.

Greens: Holy fireball Batman! The greens were fast! I'd guess that they were somewhere btwn 9-10 on the stimp meter. I was totally surprised on the first green b/c I had putted like I would normally putt and it flew past the hole!

My only complaint...and it has nothing to with the course itself, was when I was at the range...there was a guy walking around with one club in his hand and he kept hovering around the range. I finally figured out that he was like those people who hover around waiting for you to get off of a slot machine. he was watching me and waiting to see if I was going to leave balls behind so he could hit them. Talk about getting on your nerves and ruining your time for your pre-round warm up! =)
author: John K.

description:
Harding Park Golf Course is great if you don't mind paying lots of money to be treated rudely by the pro shop staff. They have major attitude. If you are a serious golfer there are many, higher quality courses in the Bay Area. Stone Tree Golf Club in Novato is incredible and you won't fight city traffic to get there. You can play a round of golf and in twenty minutes be in the wine country for dinner. Watch out for weather in San Francisco...at a recent round at Harding the wind was so violent it was impossible to play...but of course at full price. 
Most golfers are willing to travel a few miles for a great course...this is a classic course and is usually in good condition but the cons out way the pros. This is not Pebble Beach..
author: Steven S.

description: I play the Fleming 9-hole course inside of Harding Park quite often, and I love it.  The course is very well kept, the staff is usually pretty friendly, and the food at the restaurant is very good.  The only downside is the greens fee for Fleming.  It's usually $26 on weekdays, and $31 on weekends (Friday included).  The prices are not that steep, but compared to most other golf courses in the area, it is.
author: Christopher M.

description:
Beautiful executive 9-hole course at Harding.  First time here and I was impressed by how well the fairway and greens were maintained.  Came on a perfect Saturday afternoon (I know in this location it's often hit or miss).

There are no tee times (just walk-ons).  That can result in a backup on the first tee but people are patient and once we teed off, we were nicely spread that there was no wait on the subsequent holes.

Yes, a little pricey for a 9-hole ($31; $23 with a resident card), but a great option for SF (especially in comparison to some of the other public courses in the city).
author: F. P.

description:
**Disclaimer: I've only tried the driving range.  It is not a real lawn.  So, be sure to bring a lot of tees if you are hitting the driver.  

Other than that, this place is probably the best public golf course in San Francisco. The City of San Francisco seems to be putting in more money to maintain the course than others.
author: Kioko O.

description:
Beautiful 9 hole course.  Although the greens look fast because the course is so well groomed, it is not that fast.  What a wonderful way to spend an afternoon.  

$20 with a resident card.
author: HY L.

description:
A challenging, interesting course that needs some TLC and better management. The conditions as of now are miserable for what they charge (especially for out-of -SF players.)

We played it yesterday, and specifically asked in the pro shop if there was anything we should know. They should have mentioned that the 7th fairway was closed, so it was playing as a 150 yard par 3 from a temporary tee. It might have been good to know that there were 6' diameter holes dug in the fairways of a few holes (helpfully marked with orange traffic cones!) Saying that "it's a little wet out there in spots" means you're going to lose properly struck balls--in the fairway--to plugged/buried lies. Or that the greens were a mixed bag of bent, poa, bare spots and bumps that never acted the same from one green to the next. Or that they haven't mowed anything in a week. Or that the practice green was closed--at 10AM on a non-rainy day. WHY?

The sound of gunfire from a nearby shooting range can be a distraction as well. 

Maybe I'll try again after the Schwab Cup; it seems like they put on a good show when they know company is coming.
author: MARK P.

description: Pretty good 9-hole course.  If I lived closer, I'd probably play here more.   Play is slow, but not super slow.
author: Michael E.

description:
I'm a new golfer.  So, it's important to me to have a beautiful course that's actually playable for a newbie like me.

Well, this place combines both.  The greens, for the most part, were well groomed.  The course is in great shape.  And, while it challenged me, it was very playable for a rookie.   

 All of the Cypress trees are so beautiful and frame the course in very well.  And, the price is good, not great...thirty bucks for a non-SF resident on the weekend.  Can't wait to return!
author: Dusty B.

description:
I have played Harding Park many times over the past 15 years.  Years ago it was a total dog track.  It was a great layout and everything it is today, except the city of San Francisco had no money to put towards it.  Hence, it was in terrible condition.

But in 1998 the US Open was played at The Olympic Club right across the lake.  And during The Open, they used Harding Park as a parking lot for spectators.  The USGA rented it out and in return gave a huge chunk of money to the course to renovate it.  They also did this with the idea of making it worthy of professional events.

Today it is completely renovated and hosts either a PGA, LPGA or Senior event every year.  They rotate between the three.  This year in October will be the Presidents Cup with the US team competing against an International team.
  
Here is the http://www.coursecam.com/courses/harding_park_golf_course.cfm satellite map of Harding Park

If you zoom out the map a few clicks you can see the Olympic Club and the San Francisco Golf Club.  Both of which are private and I've sadly never played.

If you're going to play Harding Park here are a few things to consider.  First, if you get a cart, its cart path only.  This pretty much defeats the purpose of having a cart in my book.  Second, they have really narrowed the fairways and started growing up the rough.  So although the fairways are wide between the trees, the actual mowed fairways are quite narrow.  Third, the course is lined with giant cypress trees.  Incidentally cypress trees are my favorite, the look like giant bonzi trees.  And finally, tee times are being limited as they get closer to the Presidents Cup.

Harding Park is also a little pricy and tee times can be difficult to get.  They offer San Francisco residents a residence card for $45 which you have to buy at city hall.  This cuts the rate to about $65 prime time.  They have a Bay Area rate of about $95 and finally a out of area rate of around $125.  Once you have a residence card you can then use the automated telephone system to get a tee time, but you'll need to book about two weeks out to secure a decent time.
author: Jeremy C.

description: TPC Harding Park is a very good municipal golf course. The design and layout are solid and it is very well maintained. However, it is a city course, not a private course at a country club. As a result, you will see maintenance workers and have some distractions while you are playing, even in the middle of the day.  Also, you may run into the occasional employee with a bit of an edgy attitude.  I think it is a decent value at the local resident rate but I am not sure it is worth the out of town rate of $165.  This rate included a cart I did not need or use but did not include range balls.  That meant another $9 to hit a medium bucket off of mats.
author: Patrick D.

description: Played 7-26-14, horrible experience,  for 155$ I expected it to be a nice place and that it was, the problem we had was the maintenance crew, every single hole but 3, there was either someone running an edger or scrapping up crap off the sidewalk with a medal shovel loud as hell, all during your swing, no courtesy. Can't forget the guy driving the blower around all day, again very loud, he was nice enough to throttle down and not dust us out when he went by, only to get back to the cart and see both drinks filled with dirt and grass in them. Cant forget gun range across the water also adds to the nonsense. Finally had peace and quiet on last 3 holes, but when you pay this kind of money you expect a quiet, peaceful and enjoyable experience which we did not receive. I'm not sure if Friday is there maintenance day or they were getting ready for an event but I probably won't be going back. 1 star for the nice course,
author: Chris B.

description:
Unbelievable, did someone just write if I'm paying $100 I don't wanna be told to hurry up? Stay home so you don't ruin it for the rest of us that have to follow you. Think about others for a change. The marshals don't tell people to speed up play enough so for them to have said something to you probably means you were causing a bottleneck. City courses are notorious for slow play so it is nice to see the facility trying address a major problem-slow play. Good for them. 

Harding is a great layout. Used to play it 30x a year. Absolute gem.  Main problems IMO are pace of play which isn't surprising for a municipal course.  I think the conditioning is good enough although it varies, winter time it tends to be a little spotty and soft. But it's a must play.
author: Yong K.

description: As far as public courses go this is pretty good.   Greens are nice and the layout is fun.  It's not particularly difficult as it's very flat so a good track to play if you need an ego boost.  I would prob rate it a 4/5 if it weren't for the pro shop guys and the food.   Both God awful.   Arrived 30 minutes prior to tee time.   Waited in line 20 minutes and then were told we were checking in late lol.  They take themselves a bit too seriously.  Also, the lil snackshack they have is convenient but all 4 of us grabbed a bite and they were 0/4.   Almost inedible.   All in all not bad, but I'll play Presidio whenever I'm in SF
author: Chad H.

description:
