Although this course was renovated a few years ago to get attention from the PGA, I think a round here is a waste of money.  The customer service here is extremely poor.  The guys behind the counter at the Pro Shop act like this is Pebble Beach!  And they treat you like a hacker.  Compare that to nice courses that treat everyone like the PAYING CUSTOMERS THAT THEY ARE, regardless of appearance, ability, or dare I say RACE.

Although the starters are generally nice, the marshals are very rude.  I once teed off as part of a foursome on #1, with two open holes in front of us.  Around #5 and then later #10, the marshal was trying to speed us up to catch up to the group in front of us.  Odd.  

It should also be known that during the US Open 2012 at nearby Olympic Club, Harding decided to price gouge!   SF and CA resident rates were not honored; this is especially hard to understand because the SF resident card is a PURCHASED discount card.  In addition, visitors from out of town had to pay more than a 100% mark up greens fee!  Taking advantage of golfers, especially those who support the course year round, is simply uncouth and unprofessional.  And gouging tourists during a historical event is very un-San Francisco.

By the way, you aren't allowed to drive carts on the fairway.  So have fun crisscrossing fairways by foot all day long.  And the marshalls wonder why rounds take a long time.

Don't even bother with the crappy driving range.  The balls are old and deformed.  The fake grass surface they use is poor quality astro-turf.  It is nearly impossible to tee up your ball to practice with your driver and three wood.  

All in all, save your cash and skip Harding.  There are fantastic courses outside of the city for a fraction of the price, with better service and facilities, and quality golf.  If you MUST play in SF, Presidio has slightly better service and comparable quality golf; however, know that Presidio also price gouged during the US Open.  I'm not a big fan of Lincoln Park, but the view on 17 is fantastic and the course is a short, fun (albeit "winter rules" quality), wanna-be-long-hitters paradise.
author: M G.

description:
This is a great course, especially if you're a San Francisco resident with a resident's card.   I've been playing Harding ever since the old days when 6 hour rounds were the norm.  Now, the pace of play is day and night. The last time I played here on a weekend, we finished our round at around that 4 hour range.   The course was in excellent condition.  The greens were rolling true and the rough wasn't that bad.   

My only gripe is the golf carts.  They have these nice GPS equipped golf carts, but they have a cart path only rule so it renders them useless.  Depending on your golf game, you can walk just as much as with a cart than without, especially if you tend to hit the ball to the opposite side of the golf cart.

I keep reading reviews about the service or lack there of, but have never had an issue here.  The people at the front desk are always friendly. To me. The starter is always friendly and nice.  The golf cart ladies are always smiling and nice.
author: Milton W.

description:
$20 to play 9 holes in san francisco is a steal (with residence card, $25 without)  

Well maintained greens and holes that make you play many different clubs.  (agree with Mike G. about the vicious doglegs).   Hole 7 is a 425 yd. Par 4


Didn't have to wait for a tee time.  Excellent staff in clubhouse and course (I didn't feel that they treated us any less for playing on Fleming Course instead of Harding).

Will be back to play again many more times on this beautiful course.
author: E S.

description: I like this place. Its clean and feels like you are away from The City. But the gun fire from the shooting range brings you back to reality.
author: Miguel C.

description:
There are few municipal courses that are as good as Harding Park. The course is just challenging enough to keep you interested, and just fair enough to keep you coming back again, and again (and again). Walk the course - DO NOT RIDE as it is cart path only. It is a very easy walk, and you can pick up a trolley at the pro shop. SF regulars (lets call us *members*) do not play the blues unless we regularly shoot below 80; You should make the same self assessment when you hit the first tee.
You are not gonna shoot 100 at Harding, and you prolly aren't going to shoot 72 - it's gonna be somewhere in between, and that usually means you had a pretty good time.
author: David L.

description:
Update. What a difference a year makes with the PGA taking over. I love playing here now. 
1. Professional and courteous
2. Pace of play much better if the marshals are out
3. Quality of players has improved dramatically.

Good job guys
author: Fool G.

description: It was a decent course.  The layout was nothing too impressive.  Not too terribly long.  I did catch it on a calm morning so that probably helped with the length.  Fairways were in good shape but the greens were absolute garbage.  They were slow and there must have been 4 different types of grass on them.  I got a bay area discount but it was still $90 walking.  Might be worth it if you can get sf resident rates.  I did get a sweet looking ball marker though.
author: Kris P.

description:
Was really looking forward to playing this TPC venue. Friends said it was a great track. went to the Presidents Cup there a few years ago.
Good: 4 of the last 5 holes are really pretty overlooking Lake Merced.
The fairways are immaculate.
Made 2 birdies, shot 84.
Beautiful S.F. and played with good buds.
Bad: The greens are in horrible shape, the Poa Ana is super bumpy.
No 90degree rule. Should have walked instead of playing back & forth to the cart. Added a huge amount of time to our game.
There was  constant gun fire from the shooting range across the lake for 4 1/2 hours plus!
Golf is supposed to peaceful and tranquil, not a scene out of Saving Private Ryan.
The starter was the rudest person I've  ever met when I arrived at the 1st tee(especially after paying $113!). No "welcome to TPC Harding Park, thanks for coming" All we got was lecturing and bitchin'
End Result: I will never play there again or encourage my friends to do so.
author: Dave L.

description:
If you are a San Francisco resident this may be a good deal. 
But, for anyone else paying $150.00 ea for a round do not waste your $$$$$
There are many TPC courses where you can enjoy some great golf and scenery without being punished by this place and some of the "local" attitudes. 

Save your money and get out of town.
author: Alan S.

description:
The bbq pit isn't too shabby. Their restrooms are mirror-less and badly lighted, but they have paper towels in there and aren't too dirty. 

The garbage cans suck, but overall the grass and environment is clean. It's a fine place for large groups to have a barbecue and play light activities of football and frisbee and baseball.
author: Carl Z.

description: so was very excited to play this PGA course.  $175 with cart was a little stiff, but figured its a famous course, why not spend the extra $.  well starting at 11am on sat, the police officers across the lake start their firing range practice.  very annoying. thus the 3 stars, especially since I am paying a premium to play on this course. pace of the course I must say moves very fast considering it is a sat.  we should finish within 4 hours, which is quite amazing for a sat.  course condition is a 4 star.  the driving on the cart path ONLY is also a bother for me, call me lazy, I am fine with that, but good thing its a narrow course.
author: Anthony L.

description:
Came here another day to playing with my shitty golf skill. OK yea, "play", not really a practice. I never want to be pro player anyway. Always enjoy the breeze mixed with greens very much, although a bit windy. Remembered long time ago, I ran once over here around the lake with a nice view but short breath. It's just too bad I wasn't good runner and I'm still not. 
Long story short, from driving range, pro shop, restaurant to people work here, very friendly as I remembered. Only reason I gave 1 star short is, I'm not golfing well... lol Lame excuse, I know. Haha
author: Flora F.

description: five stars for the course. I love the condition on the fairways and green. The course is beautiful. The three stars is actually direct towards the staffs in the club house. They are rude and stuck up. I had tee time at 10am for a threesome. We arrived at 9am. The staff said that we've got some time. So, we went to the driving range. Hit a couple of buckets of balls and didn't hear our names called. We went in at 9:50am and the staffs told us that we had lost out tee time. Must check in 15 minutes before tee time! We were there all along!  Stupid ignorant workers!
author: Dee L.

description:
Granted, there are some amazing private courses nearby (Olympic Club, etc.) But this is THE San Francisco course for us regular folk. The resident's card is the only way to go, and the full boat price for non-locals is a bit or two steep. But the course is beautiful and has the majestic feel of a serious, mature track. The Presidio is also majestic, but poorly maintained and full of flaws. Forget Lincoln. Forget Crystal Springs. Harding is a bona fide crusher. The back 9 is excellent, and the finishing hole is seriously prime time. Heard a story/rumor about Padraig Harrington, who when given the chance for a warm up round before a major tournament (I believe the British Open), chose Harding because of the weather and the muscular structure of the course. Rings true to me. 

However, I've dinged them a star because the driving range is an absolute embarrassment! Terrible astroturf situation where they have synthetic "long grass". There aren't any tees, and the surface is too hard to put in your own. Ugly, and all but useless.

One more thing: if you aren't a 10 handicap, for the sake of the rest of us, stay off the blue tees! Because when the tees are back and the wind starts to blow, you and that slice-spewing driver of yours are no match for this outstanding course. Those who play according to their ego instead of their proper handicap slow down play on what can be either a 4.5 hour or 5-hour round. (depending on the day and crowd).
author: Tom M.

description: The setting is gorgeous. The staff is friendly. I had lunch at the clubhouse on March 5, 2013, with friends, and I should have sent my Salmon Angel Hair Pasta back to the kitchen. The pasta was mushy. The salmon dry. The squash and mushrooms in the pasta were soggy. It looked and tasted like it was warmed-up leftovers. I did mention my displeasure to the waitress. She said she would tell the chef/cook. I have never ever sent food back. Now I feel fortified to do it in future. [This review was posted on March 6, 2013, but today I no longer see it.]
author: Patty F.

description:
First let get the bad and the ugly out of the way.  THE Pro shop staff gets a big thumbs down.  I'd actually like to give one particular man the one finger salute.  VERY rude and not a pleasant or even friendly experience. 

The course itself is beautiful.  Albeit Dangerous at times.  Many parallel/crossing fairways.  Several Tee Boxes directly behind the previous green.  Dangerous spot to be in.  We were hit once in the cart and almost hit again in the fairway.  Crazy course.  The greens were just sanded and not enjoyable to play.  OK almost impossible to play.
author: Elaine S.

description:
I was lucky enough to sneak out here at Harding Park with not long ago, and enjoy a pleasant if chilly and socked-in summer morning round with an old friend and a couple of his unsuspecting colleagues.

In getting out early, the pace of play was good, unlike memories past of 5 and a half hour death marches here on weekend afternoons trying to race the sundown.

This course is a really enjoyable walking course with a challenging but fair layout.  We played from the blue tees at which the course plays over 6700 yards.  That means even good drives leave long irons to the greens, and if you are not striping it off the tee, expect a lot of hacking out of the rough.

If you're not a San Francisco resident card holder, find someone who is and have them call a week in advance to set you up with a tee time.

Hey Cam: Were you able to collect on those eight $5 Nassau's we won from wiping out those Berkeley alums?  Paypal me!
author: Brad P.

description: Great location, great golf course, but lousy attitudes among the workers at the pro shop and the starter.  I live close to the course and have been playing consistently since the renovation.  The workers there have consistently displayed snotty attitudes.  I don't know where the arrogance comes from.  Would it hurt them to greet patrons or just smile once in a while.
author: Daniel C.

description:
It is UNBELIEVABLE how much maintenance goes on during the middle of the effing day at this course. Honestly, it frequently feels like the golfers get in the way of the work being done between 10am-3pm.

To Harding Park management: I say this out of love for my home course, but the experience is consistently abysmal and pathetic. Something has to change.
author: Ash C.

description:
We played the course the Thursday after the Presidents Cup and arrived around 7 am. It was busy in the club house and they had a sign posted that you had to check in 1/2 hour prior to tee time.....what a great concept. There were a bunch of guys there who were trying to get out and were on the waiting list, we had made our tee time a week prior with no problem. It was pitch black at 7, but they told the first group to head to the tee. Only problem was the grill didnt open until 8 am, and our tee time was 7:50.

There had been a terrible rain storm on Tuesday, and they told us they had lost a bunch of trees and there was debris on the course....it was true, but the course was in GREAT shape.....except for the long wet rough that I was in all day.

It was a strange day, sun, mist/rain, clouds........and very damp. Being off the fairway was brutal and my score showed it (92). I would give one piece of advice, I am a 12.2 handicap and I played the blues at 6500 yards and slope of 125---it plays much longer and much tougher!! It was really cool to get to play with all of the bleachers and corporate tents still in place!

As for the course itself it is solid, a very good muni track. On the front side there are 3 holes that run side by side like a traditional muni course, and balls were all over the fairways, but it was in great shape. 17 and 18 are great finishing holes.

Best part of all was the pace of play.....we walked and finished in just under 4 hours!!!! Never felt rushed and only waited a few times for the groups in front of us.

Oh, and the course hot dog at the turn was SPECTACULAR......a great roll and huge dog.....

At the price point however I would be tempted to play Presido instead.......

Total - $135.00
author: Matthew W.

description:
Review moved over from "Harding Course" listing.

Original review written 8/8/06, updated 1/9/08:
There is usually almost no/little wait for the 9-hole Fleming course at Harding Park.  No reservations needed for Fleming, just walk on.  Nicely kept, especially for a muni course (thanks to the Harding side's PGA renovations).  $30 w/o a resident card, $22 with resident card on weekends.  It's such a pain in the ass to get an SF resident golf card (~$45) but I got one anyway.  You have to go to city hall in person during business hours and bring proper proof of residence.

The driving range is pleasant too.  It has enough available spaces and it's wide, open air, and long (unlike the one at Golden Gate Park).  $5 per bucket.  Bring $1 or $5 bills.  No change machine.
author: Chris P.

description:
I hate to be the one who "firsts" Fleming, given how many other people have reviewed it under Harding's banner, but Fleming deserves its own review. I got out and played Fleming for the first time today, and it is a wonderful 9-hole course for fine-tuning your game.

The course plays par 30 - so there are six par 3 holes and three par 4's. Think of it as a mini-Harding. Fleming plays on the interior of Harding's back 9 - and if you've ever played Harding you've at least seen some of the yellow flags marking Fleming's layout.

The holes vary in length from easy to reach par 3s of 130 yards to "hit & hope" 235 yard par 3's. The par 4 holes are fair tests of golf, varying from 400 to 450 yards from the white tees, when they are moved back.

I walked on at noon on a Wednesday. The pro shop staff were extremely courteous (I love those guys at Harding, really I do), got me processed and out the door in less than two minutes. The course itself was near-empty. I saw a few groups ahead of me, but never caught them. I had the green light to hit when ready for the entire round.

I played 9 holes in under 90 minutes. Alone. With a lot of the same views you get while playing Harding and (this is the important part) the same condition fairways & greens. The greens at Fleming are in great shape, better than Lincoln, GGP, Sharp or Glen Eagles. In fact, the only muni in town with greens close to or better than Fleming's are...Harding!

Fleming has all of the same amenities as Harding: clubhouse, range, practice greens, etc. It is the best "executive course" in the city, and my new found home for quick rounds.

Course design/playability: 4 stars 
Walk-Ability: 5 stars
Condition/maintenance: 5 stars
Driving range/practice area: 4 stars
Pace of play: 5 stars
Avg. wait for tee time: 5 stars
Pro shop staff: 5 stars
author: Greg Q.

description:
If you are looking for a 9 hole golf course that feels like simply 1/2 of an 18 hole course--this is not your course.  Go to Gleneagles and prepare to be frustrated because Gleneagles is just down right tricky.  Fleming is not that tricky.  But it is no walk in the park either--for that go to the park, literally, and check out Golden Gate park's 9 hole course.  Fleming is very well kept up, the holes are not too difficult and not too easy, and there are a few par 4's that are decently long and allow use of woods and long irons.  I played this morning for the first time and truly enjoyed myself.  The location in gorgeous as it is set in the middle of the 18 hole course at Harding park, right on lake merced.  Good golfing in the city.  Can't beat that.

****Update****
Have now become a somewhat-regular at Fleming.  I love it more every time I play.  The upkeep is killer and for a 9 holer it is hard to beat.  And there is hardly ever a wait.  Get the hint?  This is a great course, check it out.
author: Blake W.

description:
I want to give this course 5 stars but I can't because of the gun range across the lake.  Constant shots being fired during the entire round... I know its not Hardings fault, but definitely got annoying after a while.

Besides that, Harding is GREAT.  Easy to walk, course is well taken care of, and the club house is pretty nice too. Oh and the price with resident card is unbeatable.
author: shaun l.

description:
I don't know how good a deal it would be without my resident's card, in fact, I may be quite disappointed considering that the weather is nice so infrequently.  The place is well kept, the staff is friendly, and they keep groups moving along at a good pace.

For $45, it's a steal.  Thank you SF taxpayers for subsidizing Harding because I've hear that they lose a ton of money each year.

Auf
author: Dave K.

description:
Fleming course: Not bad for beginners like me.

Definitely a good 9-hole test for anyone beginning the game to see how he/she will fare against a decent course.  From the men's tee, there are 3 par-4's ranged in the 260-425yds (two of them are difficult dogleg left), 3 long par-3's in the 190-235yds, and the rest are short par-3's 140-165yds that will test your ball placement skills (avoiding trees and greenside bunkers).  The place is well kept for a public course that sees a good amount of players.  Greens aren't bad either.  Be sure to look for the sprinkler head yardage markers or bring a Skycaddie.

Just like others have said, there is hardly a wait typically on the first tee, although play can get really slow (2+ hrs) when you catch up to the groups in front of you.  Went there on a Saturday afternoon around 4:30pm and had to wait for two foursomes off Hole 5 235yds par 3.

$30 green fee on weekends ($22 with SF resident card).  They have a nice range with about 25 stalls at $5 for 50 balls, but it can get really crowded especially during weekends.
author: King L.

description:
I live in the East Bay area and had the opportunity to play Harding Park over the July 4th holiday (on Sunday).  I was very excited since I have heard so much about the course.  The setting is beautiful, but the noise level was horrific.  What noise you may ask?  Did you know that there is a gun club across the lake from the golf course.  For 4 1/2 hours I felt like I was in a Wild West shootout.  We paid $228 (inc. cart) for 2 people and had to listen to guns all afternoon.  It was ridiculous.  Spoke to the GM after the round and apparently most people there are used to the noise.  Come on!!  We played on a Sunday - it should be quiet.  I was told that the gun club is used 3-4 times a week.  And on top of that the S.F. swat team practices there.  Really!!!  What the heck does that sound like. 

And for you ladies out there - there are no restroom facilities on the course.
I found one port-o-potty on the 14th. Not good!  Course conditions were OK but not great.  Slow greens.  Too many walkers.

There are too many great courses in this area that are a lot less expensive and don't "live" next to a gun club.  In my opinion, Harding Park is not worth the money. I won't go back. :(
author: Barbara T.

description:
Harding Park is a fabulous SF golf course.. with a resident card, it's a great deal too...  I mean, $40 for a PGA quality course is hard to beat..  The Amex Championship will play here in October..

Since they lengthened it out a few years ago, the course is in great shape and now drains pretty well...

The course is challenging and really fun to play -- Not every hole warrants hitting driver off the tee, and some interesting doglegs make playing at Harding an enjoyable thinking game.  From the back 9 you can look across the lake and see the Olympic Club... 

Also not to be missed is the 9 hole short course, Fleming...
author: Dennis Y.

description:
UPDATE:  USING A CART WITH "CARTPATH ONLY" RULES ADDS 1/2 HOUR TO A ROUND OF GOLF.  IT'S A FACT.  FACTOR IN THE EXTRA TIME AS WELL FOR ALL THE VISITORS PLAYING THE COURSE FOR THE FIRST TIME AND THE 1/2 HOUR STRETCHES EVEN LONGER!

What a great layout!  And you play the same grounds as golf's current greatest pro's play (Amex, Presidents Cup, etc).

With a residents card it's a steal  Without the card it's a "play it once in awhile when you can afford it".

Harding Park - can I suggest something?  I know the visitors pay a premium and a cart is included, but with the Cart Path Only rule in effect it's much better for them to take a Pull-Cart.  All too often I get paired up with visitors who take the cart only to wait forever for them to walk all the way across the fairway to only have to walk back because they have the wrong club.  It's a flat course and 99% of the visitors can handle the walk and everyone will have a much more enjoyable experience.
author: Brian H.

description: played there today...the course sure plays long. i hit a lot of 5 woods for my second shot. course is in great condition. i hate the cart path rule only though. it is hard id you hit away from the path. a long walk back and forth. pretty cold in harding. bring your jacket. course is pretty pricey even if you are a resident.
author: robby r.

description:
It's a wonderful course but, it would be nice to be able to get a tee time before noon. It seems like all the best tee times are given to "regulars". Even with my resident card green fees are still a bit pricey for my taste.

If you enjoy Harding then I suggest you try Blue Rock Springs(Vallejo). Just as beautiful and actually the East Course is a joy to play. Challenging, yet not too tough to the point where you get frustrated.
author: Mario O.

description: This is one of the better 9-hole courses I've played: a nice combination of short and long holes.  I also like it since it's so close to home.  The only thing is I feel bad from the folks who don't have a resident card and have to pay fully price: sorry guys.
author: Dan B.

description: This place is a total gem for a public course - with the city resident card you can't beat the price.  It plays a little slow, even during the week, but it is in great shape, and extremely fair.  Live it!
author: Bill F.

description:
What a way to end the day after a golf game at Harding.  For one thing, it is hard to get tee time there and this is our first time back since renovation.  When we went to check in, we noticed the Happy Hour sign for the Clubhouse.  They had hamburger and fries for $5.00 and they had some alcohol beverages for $3.00, such a Margarita, Bloody Mary, and beer.  We decided to give it a try after our game.  We all ordered the hamburger and fries.  The hamburger was delicious.  It is simple, but delicious...a half pound patty, lettuce and tomato on a sesame bun.  The fries were the best to me...thin fries, really crispy, not burnt and not oily.  We all agreed that this was the best hamburger we have had in a long time.  

As for the drinks, I wanted a blended Margarita, but they only had it on the rocks.  I passed on this but my friend ordered one.  I normally like my Margaritas blended, but upon taking a sip from my friend, it was quite delicious.  I had to order one for myself.

Not only is the food great, so is the atmosphere.  The clubhouse is surrounded by glass windows where one can sit by the window and look out at the 18th hole, at the lake or watch the sunset.  Or, if you are a sports enthusiast, there are two flat screen TVs with different games going on.

This place is great for families also.  When we were there, there was a family of 8 having a great time and enjoying their meals.

I would definitely go back.
author: Mary C.

description:
Let's face it, there's not many great golf courses to choose from in SF.
Fleming is a 9 hole - reasonable price, and it's first come first serve.  
It's a beautiful and well kept course, along w/ a clean & newer type of clubhouse facility - gotta love it.
author: Meredith K.

description:
Best Public Course in The City hands down.

Only Glen Eagles is tougher. The conditions are always perfect. Oh yeah the PGA plays here too. Get a residents card or its $110+ to play with cart $92 to walk I think.

Some of the players and most of the staff here are pretentious as hell but at the price you gotta kind of expect it.  

I'm a Hacker so maybe that's why they're on my ass but I paid too so F@*k You guys relax you'll live longer, Golf is still a game and meant to be fun. And thats why you dont get The big 5 stars.
author: Scotty B.

description:
This is a 4-star track and a 6-star value with a resident card.  Playing a course of even remotely equivalent quality during peak times for $60 is unheard of in the bay area.  Every once in a while some minor problem reminds you that it's a muni -- the sand has become pretty hardpacked and the rakes are terrible, for instance -- but at such a low cost it's easy to ignore.

And for AP, the 1-star whiner below--

Golf is NOT a 'game of privilege.'  Harding is a public course that has no income, race, gender, orientation, or skill requirements.  Instead of getting fucked up one of these coming Saturdays, go to bed, get up early on Sunday, buy a set of clubs for $20 at a yard sale, and play the Fleming course for another $20.  You'll have fun, meet new friends, enjoy the outdoors, be introduced to a challenging and rewarding pastime, and get some exercise for less than the cost of one night at a bar.
author: S P.

description:
Beautiful course - one of the best in San Francisco!
I bit pricey but good for SF resident card holders.
They have a great First Tee program that my son likes a lot.
author: S E.

description: Fantastic course and great value for SF residents WITH a golf card. If you're a non-resident, it's pretty expensive. The course gets a lot of play, but it's well maintained. The weather, well, it's SF by the ocean, so breezy and often cold/foggy. There's a nice 9 hole course, too!
author: Lefty R.

description:
Enjoyable course in great condition since the reconstruction for the Amex WGC Championship.  The greens are in great shape as are the majority of fairways.  Of all the City of SF owned courses, this is by far the nicest.

Not the best of tracks for beginners.  Holes like #18 can quickly become frustrating for high handicappers.

I do not live in the city and thus do not qualify for the elusive Resident golf card which makes this a binary situation.  If you have one of the coveted cards, you would be crazy to golf anywhere else given the price versus the quality of the course.  If you don't live in the city, there are too many other courses in slightly better condition for a lot less money to make Harding Park worth the cash.
author: Robert M.

description:
Get a resident's golf card.

Then go play one of the best municipal cources in the entire nation.

This place is fantastic.

Call ahead.  Tee times are hard to come by on the weekends.
author: Matthew R.

description: My home course, learned to play here and have been coming through the bad (really bad) days to the current TPC days. Greens are flat and never that fast but the course plays longer than you would think (cool, heavy air). There are a number of people playing the blues that have no business there, but finishing post 5 hours is uncommon.
author: Todd L.

description: Played 3 days after the Charles Schwab Championship got over. The course is in immaculate condition. Couple of quibbles though: first, the fairways were quite moist and the roll the pros were getting on Sunday was not to be seen, and second, where is the drinking water on the course? Not a water fountain or container to be seen anywhere.
author: mukul k.

description:
This is a fine little golf course in a beautiful section of SF. Hidden inside of the Harding 18, you'll see fairways stretching in every direction, giving you the feeling of playing a large, luxurious course. Yet you paid $22 and you can finish your round in less than 2 hours.

Fleming is a great place to learn golf, which is why I've been coming here regularly for the past 5 months or so. A step up from GG Park in terms of difficulty, since there are 3 par 4's - two of them with vicious doglegs that make it very hard to garner a clean second shot.  You can bust out your woods and large irons and really go for it; but be careful because those Montery cypress trees really overhang a lot of the holes and can knock your ball sideways in a jiff. The rough is also, well...rough.

A fine place to come during the week - I've hit it up early-style before work a few times and been the only guy out there - or on the weekend, when you might wait 20 minutes if it's crowded.
author: Mike G.

description:
This is one of my favorite Bay Area golf courses. Since the redesign, it's gone from an OK public course to a world class gem. The views are outstanding,  and the course is well maintained.  This is a course to walk since it's relatively flat (don't bother with a  cart unless you need one, since carts generally are not allowed on the fairways - not even 90 degrees).

If you're a San Francisco resident with a Resident's Card, Harding Park is the best deal around ($48 dollars on the weekends compared to $138 for non-residents). If you're a San Francisco resident without a card, stop reading this review and go get one now! It's hard to get a good advanced tee time via the phone system one week ahead of time, but if you're willing to spend an extra $10 you can get a tee time a month in advance.  The renovated clubhouse has decent food and a killer view of the 18th hole.
author: Debbie J.

description: I play here all the time and consider it my home course. It may seem a bit pricey for a 9 hole but hey, it's the city. TPC has done a good job and finally they came out with better scorecards. My son is in the first tee program here and loves it. They haven't officially ranked the red tees for the kids, but I heard that TPC has requested it.  [ FYI - the Womens' league uses 87/30.3 for slope ratings ]. It's actually a pretty challenging 9'er. Hole 5 is a 235 yd par three!. Out is a 30 as the course has 3 par 4's. This place can and will get beat up after a major is at Harding. On the good side they finally have tour grade sand! Really, the sand is now top notch!
author: garth s.

description: Great golf course for a nice day out. Great food in the bar/restaurant.
author: Jason D.

description: i really like this type of courses which i think is a grand traditional layout.  i'm not one to complain about price because i understand a course will charge what it can get based upon demand, but $150 for out of towners is a stretch.  Then again, imo, it is the best public course within SF.  Torrey Pines in SD is $250 for the south and &150 for the north course albeit with better conditions and you can ride on the fairway whereas harding is cart path only.  No doubt, SF Residents have it good like SD residents.  Its still worth the play if you don't want to leave SF and I would play it again as an out of towner.
author: Jo M.

description: Best 9 hole in the bay area.  period.  Harding is a waste of money.
author: Fatty A.

description:
Ok this place turned into one of my favorite nine hole golf course in the city (mind you it wasn't too hard considering what it competes with).

So Fleming is the nine hole golf course in Harding Park. Harding Park was just renovated in preps for the 2009 Presidents Cup. No joke both courses are NICE! 

They don't take reservations at Fleming. I got there around 11:30 with hopes of getting on the course in an hour. There was NO WAIT! It was awesome. I called my buddy whom I had planned to go golfing with, and we were off on the first tee at Noon. The marshal was nice to let me and her go as a pair.

So the course itself, was a bit tough, which I prefer. Good variety of short and long par 3's with a couple of par 4's. You can easily see parts of Harding Park, which made me want to drool. You get backed up around the 5th hole I believe, but there are so many people on there, its understandable. Just be patient and wait your turn (and remember you are on the short course). Easily walkable (its nine hole!) and a lot of fun. By the end, I had a good time and it was simple enough for me to get some golf in without dedicating my whole day to it.
author: Diana R.

description:
Upon moving back to SF after grad school one of the first items I tended to was getting my SF resident card to get the resident rate at Harding Park.  Yes, the rounds can be slow on the weekends, and yes they are maintaining the course in a different manner this summer due to the President's Cup in October.  But all in all, it's the best deal for golf in the Bay Area (with the resident card, that is).
Plus, I've had pretty good luck getting some $$ matches with the people that I'm paired up with... The back nine is also way better than the front nine as it plays around the perimeter on the course.
author: Murray H.

description:
On those rare days in the city where the sunshine exists not only in the Mission but also reaches the often dismal western reaches like the Sunset and environs, I find myself wondering if I have time to drop whatever I'm doing and run out to Harding for a round. 

Harding is a spectacular course.  Having only lived here for 2 years, I've never played it prior to renovation, but I have to say that Harding park compares favorably with my hometown local muni course, Torrey Pines.  

With a resident card, the fees are beyond reasonable, the 18-hole main course is both challenging and beautiful (the 18th hole in particular just gives me fits as every single time I've played it I've either hooked my drive into the lake, or sliced it to the right, leaving me some gazillion yards to the green).  The 9-hole Flemming is very good for what it is.  

Overall, Harding is not quite as challenging as Torrey Pines South, but   maybe one thing they do better at harding is stagger the tee times further apart so there is less time spent waiting for the group ahead.  

Getting a reservation is not too difficult if you use the phone tee time reservation system a week in advance.
author: Josh K.

description:
Played Fleming earlier today for the first time - great, little nine hole course.   Walked on at 9:30am and immediately joined another single and off we went.  Nice mix of medium and really long par 3s with three par 4s thrown in for good measure.  

Overall shape of course was excellent for a muni course - greens were in good shape.  Hands down the best nine hole golf course I've ever played.
author: Michael M.

description:
I'm a kid and i'm with Youth on course and you get a real deal, after 4 p.m. (2 p.m. in the spring) you can play Harding for $5 anf Fleming for $2
I play there every day now during summer break!
It's my home course for my summer break!
author: Shawn I.

description:
For starters, you should know that I'm a San Francisco resident who plays out of Gleneagles - so I'm no prima donna when it comes to course conditions. I'm also no stranger to Harding as I regularly play there 4-6 times a year. This morning I went out in the first group of the new year and found the conditions to be abyssmal.

All of the greens were covered with blotches - due to an infestation of poa annnua grass, fungus, and in some cases, weeds. As a result, most of them were bumpy and a few were nearly unplayable.

The fairways and rough were completely overwatered and there was mud and muck everywhere on the course. In fact, the middle of one fairway on the front nine was cordoned off because it was too muddy and there were several other fairways that should have been given the same treatment. All this despite the fact that there's been very little rain over the last few weeks. Most of the fairways were also covered with small mud balls. At first I thought they had been punched (aerated), but one of my playing partners told me that when the ground is completely saturated, earthworms burrow their way to the surface. They leave behind displaced dirt, which due to overwatering - does not dissolve, but turns into the aforementioned mud balls.

As any San Francisco golfer knows, none of this would be worth discussing if it was about any other city-owned course. The problem is that we're talking about Harding Park - where non-residents are charged $89 - $155 to play golf on a weekend or holiday; where the course requires a public subsidy to stay afloat (no pun intended); and where the staffing levels compared to other city-owned courses (and parks) are outrageous.

Unfortunately, Harding's level of staffing doesn't result in anything remotely approaching fine playing conditions. Think I'm exaggerating? Take this morning...I saw more people working in the area of the 12th green and 13th tee than Gleneagles employs to maintain the entire golf course. You know what they were out there doing today on "holiday" pay? They were cleaning out the gutters between the concrete slabs of the cart path! 

Perhaps you'll think I'm being overly harsh; but as a golf-playing, property tax-paying resident of San Francisco, I can't help but be outraged at the poor management of the Harding Park golf course.

By the way, the resident rate today was $60. If I'm going to spend that amount or a bit more (w/o a cart), I can think of many other well-conditioned places to play that are nearby. Perhaps you should also consider "voting with you wallet" and doing the same.
author: Cee J.

description:
BEAUTIFUL COURSE.

If you play golf, live in the city, and have a few extra dollars...play this course at least a couple times. The fairways are great. The greens are pretty consistent, and the traps make this course very challenging.

Don't expect to play a low score, just enjoy the experience. I recommend walking if they won't allow the 90* rule when you go. Getting a cart that can only be driven on the path isn't very helpful. And check in with the starter 10 minutes before tee time.
author: Josh B.

description: Great Course, but if I am playing a 100+ dollars around I don't want to be told to hurry up.
author: Naresh R.

description:
6 months ago I spoke to the GM at Harding, after a particularly horrific 5 and 1/2 hour round there, just before the TPC takeover.  The course was in miserable shape, that was late September last year.  He assured me that after the TPC takeover, "you'll see a much better product....."

Well, guess what, NOT!  Here we are, mid June, they're in charge so it's their  baby now, and the place sucks.  I've played several local courses in the last couple of weeks, San Geronimo, Rooster Run, Indian Valley, Windsor, all daily fee courses, all fantastic condition.  Firm fairways, smooth greens running about 8 or 9 or more on the Stimp, the greens all hold approach shots.  This is the competition for Harding's golf dollar within an hours drive.  

Let's get to the facts and reality currently at Harding.....

A friend of mine was here from San Diego recently and wanted to play Harding.  The $150 fee was a non starter, we went to San Geronimo for $35 and had a great time.  Let's get real here, Harding is worth $40 to walk for an SF resident, and any out of town player should be able to get on for $75.  Make the price affordable and  you'll have plenty of play.....On Monday they don't let anyone off until 8 am.  Huh?  We would have loved to go out at 7 am......what other area public course has no play until 8 am on Monday?  How much revenue does that cost the course annually?  I don't want to hear about money trouble if you can't get the place open and people off the first tee on a Monday at 7 am.  Driving range?  In shambles.  I was afraid to hit down into the uneven, lumpy fake turf there for fear I'd tear a ligament in my hands.  Time to bulldoze that piece of junk and put in a state of the art double decker driving range with quality matts and balls, which will increase revenue and allow for a decent warm up.  Putting green?   Nope, sorry closed on Monday.  So I pay my daily fee and want to hit some putts after the round but the green is closed?  R U KIDDING ME?  Again, name another course that closes the practice green on Monday.  

Now, let's get to the specifics of the golf course.  Fairways?  Patchy, dry and not mowed close enough.  I got several bad lies in the fairway because they don't mow them tight enough for the ball to sit up.  OK, so now it's finally dry out there.....the drainage system they put in works, big deal.  Now do something about the fairways, make them pure like all the rest of the area courses......Bunkers?  Not much sand, plenty of clay when you dig in with a 60 or 64 degree wedge.  The greens?  Well, they wouldn't hold a perfectly struck 8 iron from the fairway on #2, nor a perfectly struck hybrid on #3, both balls landing 10 feet or so below the hole and releasing to the back edge.  But the green speed?  Slow and slower, no one got the ball to the hole all day, probably a 6 on the Stimp.  Whoever heard of firm and slow?  Marshalls on the course?  Nope.  Pace of play?  If we hadn't been the third group off we'd probably still be out there on the back nine somewhere.......

We pay $45 a year for a residents card, and $48 to play Harding.  It's supposed to be this prestigious course that holds PGA and Champions tour events.  Reality?......it's the worst course I've played in the last few years, consistently, period.  Me and my friends, all SF residents, won't renew our residents card nor play there ever again.  Is this how the City of SF expects to foster a golf program that will be successful?  Are we to believe the hype that the new TPC status and the new management will be able to turn it int a first class golf experience?  And finally, the ultimate question, who's in charge and what the heck is going on out there?  Is this the best they can do?  Do we need to wait 5 years for it to happen?  Or, more likely, is it just more of the same old stuff?
author: Mark S.

description: Finally got a chance to play here and loved it. Great layout and a very good looking course. Not too much trouble to get into here, and a fun place to play. Very flat, so a very walkable course. There is a lot of noise from the nearby shooting area, but you will be used to it after a while. Course itself was in great condition. Got out as a single in 20 minutes. Course took 4.5 hours. Fairways and greens were great. Bunkers had good sand. Rough was patchy, some areas were thin, some thick, some bare, some were mounds of grass next to bare spots. Don't go in the rough. Had a great time and would recommend it. A little pricey, but rates are a bit cheaper than what is posted. Comes with a free cart, but do yourself a favor and walk.
author: Greg P.

description:
It s hard, it has some long holes its $90 to get on, but well worth it. Harding is an old school course that is as much a part of the city as The Bridge.  took 2 clients out for a round yesterday and they where stunned by its beauty. (and it's challenge) 

Play it! I
author: Michael V.

description: I hated this course before they refurbished it.  I think it was about 4 years ago, I had a horrible round out there and swore to never play the course again.  Well after hearing about the excellent job they did repairing the abysmal greens and fairways I gave it a shot last year and am glad that I did.  The course is now a joy to play and a pretty good deal if you are a SF resident.  The resident card pays for itself in one round and I would highly recommend.  $46 to walk on the weekends is a great value for a course this nice.  The course should start to play really tough as they narrow the fairways, grow out the rough and speed up the greens for the pros.
author: Steve S.

description:
Great course!  Well maintained and a challenging layout.  It is an average price when you dont have an SF residents card, and GREAT value if you do have one!

I would have given it a 5 star but I have two complaints, that p*ss me off every time I play.

1.  The course is not marshaled very well at the weekends, where some rounds can be greater than 5hr 30m....
2.  The Cart Lady doesn't come around often enough.  Once on the front 9 and once on the back 9 is just not enough beer!!!
author: Dazza M.

description: It's quite a beautiful golf course and you'll catch a celebrity sighting here n there.
author: James S.

description:
Our group of Barbershop singers had their annual installation dinner at the Harding Park Golf Course Clubhouse banquet room for the third time on Jan 9,2011. The arrangements, food  and service were all excellent. The wait staff were quite attentive to our needs. About 30 people attended and a good time was had by all. Thanks.
       Newton H.
author: Newton H.

description: Great golf course, challenging in every respect.  We played a few weeks after The Presidents Cup.  The greens were rolling well but not deadly fast.  The rough was grown out longer than it was in the Presidents Cup I am told.  The greens are small targets given the club you will have in your hand on your approach shot.  I shot 77 and had to chip out from the trees 3 or 4 times.  18 is an awesome hole (it was the 15th in the Presidents Cup to ensure it was played in most matches) and they still had the huge grandstand up.  I really love this golf course.  We teed off at 10:15am on a perfect day in San Francisco.  Pace of play was okay but not great.  It costs $150 for guests, $100 for NorCal residents, and $50 for SF residents if you have a playing card from city hall.  This is one of my favorite golf courses for sure.  It was a great experience.
author: chris b.

description: Its a nice golf course.  I come here during the first day of the President Cup. I volunteer with one brick and help with the concession stand near the 13th  hole.  I got in for free but work selling food.  I didn't stay for the opening, i was too tired.  The food was expensive but it was free for for me. The manager closed the concession early but some of us volunteers left early an didn't stay.
author: John F.

description: I freaking love playing here.  I wish I played here more often... With my resident card, it's such a great deal.  Problem is, most of the people I play golf with don't live in SF.  #$!@#!
author: JungHyun H.

description:
Played this course for the first time over the weekend.  Had high than normal expectations after hearing that the President's Cup was played here and that they had put millions of dollars into the renovation.

Course has beautiful cypress trees all around and is in good shape throughout.   However, the rough was cut so short it didn't offer any penalty and the course is very straight and rather short (~6400 yds from blue).  They have tried to stretch the course as much as possible, but the relatively low number of bunkers and straight layout make it rather unspectacular.  

Views are impressive of the city and you can see the Olympic Club across the way.  There was some background noise from the gun range nearby, but that didn't bother us.  What did bother us was a very over zealous starter who was more concerned about implementing some sort of military precision than having his customers enjoy themseles.  

Three stars for unspectacular course design, nasty course starter and rough that is cut way too short.
author: Mike S.

description: Nice course but didn't like "cart path only" rule. Pro shop had great service.
author: Gail M.

description: Very very average. Hard to believe it ever hosted a tournament as prestigious as the Presidents Cup. The par 3 on the right as you drive in gives you a clue as to what you are in for (I thought that was a practice hole or something). Way over priced. I am struggling to remember a single hole of note. Maybe the 18th is worthy of the hype. The condition of the course was perfectly fine though but the driving range is just terrible. I had high expectations but was severely disappointed.
author: Martin P.

description: This is an awesome course with great employees.   However, I'm a resident and only pay $48 for 18 holes at a world class facility.
author: Paul W.

description: well maintained...not surprising for a sf muni course....beautifully re-landscaped huggin' lake merced...balance mix of all hazards in the rollin' greens....adding a bit of challenge to the 18-hole harding course..yet...novice golfers can find equal fun in the simpler,,,mostly par 3...9-hole fleming course....avoid the rough....tall grass make shots difficult or drain from the swing....consider a hybrid wood to glide over the rough and knock the ball out...long irons useless in the rough...great mix for the beginner, intermediate and pro....sf resident card recommended for economical pricing....
author: Hen A.

description:
wow, harding park is muni golf the way it's *supposed* to be! fantastic course in beautiful condition. reasonably priced (for local residents, that is). nice clubhouse and driving range. PGA tour events are regularly played here, so it's neat to play the same course that the pros do!

i came for the presidents cup 2009 - my first tournament and it was surprisingly fun! i'm not usually into watching golf on tv like my husband but i figured how often do you get to see so many great golfers up close all at once? they really transformed the golf course for this event (huge tents everywhere and fleming the 9 hole course was temporarily replaced as the practice area). it got cold and foggy at times but it didn't matter.
author: Annie c.

description: This is a great course! The play always keeps moving, it's well maintained, the beer girls are prompt, what more is there to say?!?! Plus, if you want to walk-on, you can always play Flemming, which for a 9-hole is a great practice course and you need to bring pretty much your whole bag. The rangers are really nice, too, which helps when play gets a little slow.
author: Kristin D.

description: Great course, except for the shooting range across the water.  It can get pretty loud.  I can't wait for President's Cup this week!
author: Mike C.

description:
I consider myself to be a very experienced golfer and have played many golf courses in the Bay and around the world (used to play golf for Cal - go Bears!)  Very disappointed with the individuals running the Pro Shop @ Harding Park. I've tried to make tee times on several occasions and have never played because I am so turned off everytime I call them.  

I am not an SF resident (maybe this makes a world of difference???), however, I am a strong believer in treating people kindly regardless.  If you cannot accommodate, no problem.  Just be polite about it - offer some alternative dates/times.  You were like any other public golf course before the PGA gave you such recognition and now you have this idea that you're in the same exclusive ranks as the Augusta Nationals and Cypress Points.  Please check yourself.  San Francisco is a classy city and golf is a classy sport.  Please Harding Park, replace the rude, unprofessional and classless individuals in the Pro Shop and find those who can properly represent this golf course and the city of San Francisco.  Just because you are a muni, doesn't mean you have to act like one...
author: Jen L.

description: This is only a review for the driving range and putting green - as I haven't played the course in years. Apparently this is the best driving range in the city - so I haven't much to compare to - except my own experiences at other ranges in other cities. It's 'alright.' I wish they had rubber tees on the mats instead of an elevated strip down the middle of the mat. Elevated fake grass is still grass. Tee shot practice needs a tee. Other reviews say you can tee off the real grass but then you have to move forward and be practically in front of your mat- which could prove a bit dangerous if anyone near you has a bad swing. I'll tell you what isn't bad is the price of $5 for a bucket of 50. Decent.  Putting green- interesting. No actual holes to put into. Just flags to aim for and hit. Something about getting it in the cup that's kind of satisfying though. Make a hole in the green, will ya?
author: Amanda H.

description: This is a great course for 40 some odd dollars, but for those of you who are non-SF residents I'd save it for a special occasion.  The greens fees are a bit much ($130 non-resident, $90ish for Bay area) for not including a gas cart and average maintenance of fairways.  It is a fun course though and playing in the morning, we breezed through 18 in 4 hours and I was walking.  I'll go back (after I move up into SF).
author: Allen S.

description:
Copying this review for Fleming (from Harding 18 holes) at Greg Q's request.   

"Feel it is appropriate to add this course (part of Harding park) in addition to breif mention in reviews for its big, and better known bro.

Fleming, has many advantageous of its sibling in that they course and greens are kept in excellent condition, but this is the place to come if you want a 9 hole (1.5 - 2hr) vs full 18 (4hr+) experience.
They even add a couple of par 4's and the opportunity to pull the big lad out, if you are so inclined.
As with any decent course, It can get fairly busy, and slow at times, so getting an early start is often prudent. I played today at 9:30 and was done within 2 hours.

Its a bit pricey perhaps at $30 ($22 with resi card)." - 8/12/2007  

Haven't played for a wee while, as a nurse a back injury. but I shall be back
author: Ad C.

description: Best driving range in the Bay Area. Their teaching pro, Ross Kroeker, is a stud. To demonstrate how driving is all about the clubface and not the lower body, he stood on one foot and crushed a 300-yard drive. Awesome.
author: Brian M.

description:
most people are reviewing Fleming under the Harding Park business name but i'd put it under it's own name to eliminate confusion.  they are two very different courses.  Harding is a world class 18 hole, par 72, that hosts a professional tournament yearly.  Fleming is a dinky little, walk-on, 9 hole course with a par of 30 that is will run you a whopping 22 bucks if you have an SF resident card.  i mean, the toyota tercel and the Lexus LS are both made by Toyota but i don't think they are the same car.  same analogy with Fleming/Harding. 

i'll review harding later, but since i play Fleming so regularly, i'll put a review down for it first.  

First off, it's an incredible deal for $22.  The course is in amazing condition for a public course that is so affordable.  it's not like Lincoln at all where you end up hitting off of mud or the greens are patchy, at best.  the course is in great condition which makes it quite enjoyable. 

Also unlike Lincoln, it's a great course for beginners since there are almost no hazards, no water, very little sand... and there aren't any out-of-bounds areas where you can lose a lot of balls.  even if you put a ball 50 yards wide, you will probably just land on a fairway for one of the Harding holes.  the fact that it's so good for beginners, of course, has it's downsides.  that means that there ARE a lot of beginners; a lot of people chasing a lot of balls on other fairways; a lot of people shooting an 8 on the par 3's!  So come there with patience.  you could end up watching the group in front of you take 7 shots each to get to the green on the 190 yard, hole #3.  so if you're a decent player, you probably want to play at an odd hour or on a cloudy, cold day so there aren't so many hackers on the course.  the wait is usually not bad.  it's walk-on only and unless you go on a crowded, sunny weekend it's very manageable.  

if you want to get detailed about it then i'd say that hole 1 is the hardest hole of all.  it's 400+ yards but a tough, tough dog-leg left.  my advice is don't use a driver because those trees in front of you are only about 200 yards away so if you can hit a driver over 200 yards, you will end up behind the trees with no shot at the green.  take a wood and slap it 190 yards and push to the left.  that will, of course, leave you with a very long wood shot at the green.  good luck reaching the green in two.  it's the hardest hole.  if you get a bogey, good for you. 

the other holes are pretty straight-forward, few hazards, little sand... some over-hanging trees make some of the shots more difficult.  it's fairly challenging, all in all.  there's a 235 yard par 3.  good luck in hitting the green (and 2-putting) from 235 yards away!  there's another 200 yard par 3, also tough one to hit the green.  they make up for it somewhat with a very, very short, 260 yard, par 4 which gives you a decent chance at a birdy or at least, par.
author: dan h.

description: We had our wedding at Harding Park in October and it was beautiful! We chose the location because of Kristina, their event planner. She is very organized, friendly, and gave us a lot of confidence that she could help us put the whole thing together and make sure that it went as well as it could. Kristina really came through! She had been out for several months before and we were a bit nervous but as soon as she returned, everything fell into place. The location overlooking the lake was beautiful and in spite of the bleachers behind the site (for the golf tournament), it was perfect. The bleachers actually provided a bit of a wall which came in as a handy hiding spot for us to hang out before going down the aisle. All of the wedding details were taken care of without us having to worry about a thing on the day of it all. Cocktails, dinner, and the reception went perfectly and we had a great time.  Kristina was incredible!
author: Francesca L.

description: After this weekend and watching "pros" struggle, I feel a bit better about my golf game.  With a resident card, Harding Park Golf Course might be the best deal in the entire city.
author: Jon P.

description: Was a bit disappointed.   Paid $69.00 rate and thought that was a bit steep for the condition of the course.  Can't imagine paying the $135.00 rate.   This course is supposed to host the Presidents Cup in 9 months.  Fairways were thin and greens were very rough.   Bunkers were strange.  Appeared to have sand in them but hard as a rock just under the surface.   Probably won't play this course again.   The city needs to take better care of its golf courses.
author: Robert B.

description: Played this morning and the conditions have gotten worst since the President's Cup in October.  Greens are getting beat up and fairways are soft in a lot of areas.
author: Lance Y.

description: I haven't been here since they remodeled everything but the times I've played here I've enjoyed myself. I usually would play Flemming, but Harding treated me well and I kind of miss it, actually. It's a lot pricier now than it used to be so they've been losing a lot of local avid golfers. But, if you have the opportunity to play here I think you'd have a good experience. I like this course better than Lincoln Park though.
author: Jen Y.

description:
This course should get 5-stars, but I've got two knocks and each is worth a star.  1) impossible to get a tee time unless you plan one month ahead, which is not feasible for those w/ kids, demanding jobs, etc. and 2) the range sucks - expensive, terrible faux-grass instead of mats.
Plus, some of the staff could use a class on Customer Service 101.
author: WP D.

description:
I write this review of Harding park as a former employee of the place...in the mid-nineties (high school) I worked there as the starter and I did various odd jobs at the range as well.

Back then Harding was a little slice of heaven, easy to get on, laid back cool pros, and $20 for residents to play 18! Needless to say I played there ALL the time.

Well a few years ago they did a much ballyhooed renovation to the place, it was closed for an entire year...when it reopened it was a much better golf course, the grass was greener and the putting greens actually had a true roll. That was the only thing that improved, everything else declined dramatically. I could go on forever, and believe me I have gone on forever when I'm drinking with the guys or playing as a single with some strangers. I'll try and be brief. Maybe I'll make a list of grievances

1. You pay $45 a year for a residence card. "What the hell City of SF, why can't I just show my driver's license?" why do you need to squeeze $45 out of me a year to prove I live in the city limits!  What a racket!  

2. It's very hard to get a tee time now. As a resident you can make a tee time 7 days in advance for $1 a player. BUT if money is no object you can be a NON-RESIDENT and make a tee time 30 days in advance for $10 a person. This policy has basically taken Harding away from blue collar folks who just wanna play a decent 18 in the city they live in. I've called right on the dot at 7pm 7 days in advance to get a tee time several times with mixed results, but most of the time I go through the little automated system asking for a threesome at 8am, and they say back to be "the nearest tee time that meets you request is....11:47am, would you like to reserve?" so right at the opening the whole morning is gone and the only thing left is the 15 minutes before twilight when NO-ONE wants to make a tee time since you're paying full price for something you can have a major discount in 15 minutes...so you hang up the phone is disgust and say to yourself..."Well I guess we're hiking that day, or watching football...or...."

3. The clubhouse is one of the ugliest modern buildings I've seen in a while. Strike that it's not ugly, it just doesn't have ANY personality, one of my buddies calls it a Danville McMansion a very accurate description I think.

4. when they were talking about the renovation they said they'd keep the resident rates low and let the non-resident rates pay for the course....we'll every few months I look up at the prices and they resident rates had steadily climbed while the non-resident rates have declined. It's gotten to the point where some day in the future the benefits of the resident card might not be as great as they are today.

5. In my 15 years of playing golf I have never been told to "speed things up" but it's happened twice in the last 6 months! I'm a 10 handicap too, I don't play slow...one time I was on the 8th tee (a par three) and a marshal rolled up on us and told us to tee off when the people on the green weren't even off yet! I have dozens of stores just like this one too....

6. enough for now...just know that Harding is a great course that is in the wrong hands
author: Adrian H.

description: Wonderful course in San Francisco.  Beautiful scenery and very well kept greens.  Definately worth the money and they have a 9 hole executive course called Flemming which is fun and challenging.  I would recommend this course to anyone and with a SF residents card, who can go wrong?
author: Darren I.

description: The Fleming 9-hole course at Harding Park is one of the best kept secrets in SF. There are several long par-4 holes mixed in with par-3s, which makes it challenging for hackers and seasoned players alike. A beautiful and well-maintained course, it's a great value for your money (especially if you have a resident's card).
author: Nishan K.

description: Definitely returning to its old form... one of the best public courses in the U.S. Expect it to get better and better leading up to the Amex World Golf Championships set here for October 2005.  This place used to be the parking lot for events at the O Club... not anymore!
author: Todd J.

description: Best 9 hole course I have ever played.  There are a few long holes and the grass is pretty nice.  It is pretty cheap also, 20 dollars if I remember correctly.  I don't know cart prices because I walk.
author: Christopher D.

description:
Location: Really nice layout, weaving in and out of the trees my only thought is that too bad it couldn't be closer to the water. 

Value: Residents card is a steal, my dad was an out of towner and honestly it is over priced (still a better deal than Presidio though!)

Course: Really nice solid course, in good shape with some nice layouts.  No boring holes.

Overall: Great golf experience, awesome deal with the residents card - without it I'd probably head out of the city to Cinnabar or something else.
author: Fred J.

description: I wish ALL muni courses were like this.  Get yourself a Rec. & Parks Resident Card and the value is awesome.  Of course everyone wants to play it so it is busy.
author: Max C.

description: Beautiful, newly renovated golf course. Greens are nice, rough is thick. City of SF invested $16M to renovate and they are hosting the 2005 AMEX PGA event. Green fees used to be reasonable for locals, about $46 with a SF resident card. Highly suggest getting the resident card.
author: Ross W.

description: The well maintained public 9-hole course, Fleming, is great.  It's easy to walk-on, moves pretty quickly, and the people who play/work here are pretty mellow.  A nice place to spend a couple of hours chasing a small white ball around outdoors.
author: Tina T.

description: Unbelievable that this is a public course.  Beautiful, and definitely one of my favorite ways to spend a few hours on a sunny afternoon.  The clubhouse is nice and great for watching the game after a round of golf!
author: Christina S.

description:
I played here yesterday with my father.  We paid $22 for a resident and $19 for a senior resident.  I bit pricey for a nine hole course.

The wait wasn't too bad on a beautiful Sat. afternoon.  Most of the course is well maintained, but the greens are not that great.  We haven't even had that much rain and the greens are bumpy.  

We don't have many choices in SF for playing a quick nine holes (Golden Gate is a bit short and a lot of beginners) and McLaren is not in the best part of town.  Lincoln Park is the best deal during the week if you can get out of work.
author: Brian L.

description: A very nice course especially since they have finished renovation just in time for the Amex Golf Tournament....however, if you are in good shape to walk I would definitely recommend walking as it is a cart path only course so might as well take a pulley and walk the course as you will be running back and forth to get your clubs anyways....unless you are lucky to have a caddy with you! hehehe  BTW, for those who like to eat while playing, I highly suggest their pastrami sandwich on whole wheat....it is very tasty and I don't even like beef...
author: Mee-stique K.

description:
A true testament of what a municipalities are capable of.  Great facilities and a beautiful course.  Not nearly as challenging as I expected though. There really is no rough to speak of.  The only difficulty is that the course is long.  I thought there would be more traps as well.  

I made the mistake of riding in a cart with a buddy.  BIG mistake.  Just walk or use a pull cart.  Carts cannot leave the paths.
author: Zack S.

description:
I very much dislike the fact that you can't bring the golf carts onto the fairway, even at 90 degrees. If that's the case, why have them at all? Perhaps only make it an option for the older folk or the kids in tow? Otherwise, you end up bringing your entire bag out there and then hauling it all back to the cart after you top your second shot. Not worth it. Walking is way quicker. Rent a push cart.

OR, do what San Jose Muni and Santa Teresa do! Rent out Segways and get the best of both worlds.

That said, this is an extremely well maintained golf course and the pro shop guys are good dudes. The starters, well -- there are a few bad apples but most are genial enough. What do you want? They're starters. They're security guards without the uniforms.
author: Sean P.

description: Excellent new public course which boasts a Jack Nicholas designed course.  Also will be host to the American Express Championship this October.
author: Stephanie B.

description: Great course, great price (with City ID), & great practice area (the trees guard it so that the wind doesn't affect the ball flight too much).  It's challenging & fun.  The gun range across the lake can be kind of annoying, but that doesn't keep me away!
author: Ryan M.

description:
Harding Park is a special place for public golfers.  One of the best municipal golf courses in the entire country, it's one of few munis that have held a PGA tour sanctioned event on it with more to come.  I'd like to give it 5 stars but reserve that designation for places like Pebble, Bandon, Olympic etc..

Harding is a great test of golf and the more you get to know the course the more you appreciate it.  It's a course that requires strategy if  you would like to score well.  Some holes play differently from the blue tees so it's worth playing there at least once to see how those holes play.

On the downside, conditioning is still great although not as great when it first reopened.  Considering the play that Harding receives it's still in very good shape.  It kind of depends when you are out there.  The driving range leaves something to be desired but has one of the best short game areas in the immediate area for public golfers.  It is the place to go to practice your short game in the SF area.

On hole 13, you can see the famed fairways of the Olympic Club but golfers at Harding Park shouldn't get down too much as they are playing another gem of a course themselves.
author: Gene K.

description: I think Harding did a great job in their renovations years back, but not sure if it's worth $150 a round.    For that price I would likely select other courses first.    If you're going to play make sure to use a SF Resident Card as you'll get a healthy discount and then it's definitely worth the treck out there ..... with nice weather, the views are great too from several of the holes.
author: Jay S.

description: built at the expense of dozens of neighborhood parks.....the damn thing still can't pay for it's self!...even with the skimpy deal with amex...what a waste of tax payer dollars for such a game of privilege that caters to very few in SF.
author: A P.

description: I thought this was a great classic style course. Conditions were great, greens smooth, fairly fast, fairways well kept for a place that has a ton of play, pace of play was great (although I played early in the morning). I would definitely go back again. No tee times for singles, but you can show up and put your name on the list. Prior reviews about the course being not well kept are way off, no mud, standing water, or anything of that nature. If your considering playing here you won't be disappointed.
author: Jason E.

description: Great promise but Harding needs to do something to keep up the standards ? Last time i played it was very average, I would never pay more than resident rates to play Harding, good value for residents, below par for visitors.
author: martin d.

description: Its been four months since Jen L's review and they obviously havent looked into their staffers defiencies.  When she played, I guess they thought they were the best ticket in town, which they obviously aren't.  I played after the President's Cup.  And now, apparently, their sh!t doesn't stink.  The only, and I mean only polite person I met on their staff was the starter.  And he had no idea what he was doing because we finished the first hole and were ready to move to the second.  But the foursome ahead of us was waiting for the foursome ahead of them to TEE OFF.  You heard it right.  There were TWELVE people on the second tee box.
author: JEFFREY J.

description: If you are not a San Francisco resident it is too expensive to play here. No way can the green fees be justified.
author: Venkat N.

description: SO rude! My sister previously wanted to play there and when she called she spoke with someone who was completely rude and would not help her at all. Granted, I called there today to try and set up a tee time for my Dad for Father's Day. I am a resident of San Francisco. In asking to set up a tee time, I let them know I was a resident and taking my Dad for Father's Day. In doing so, they proceeded to tell me that I only could receive the resident rate, my father would be charged the full rate because it is about where the "golfer" is a resident. I asked that even though I was taking my Dad and paying for him as a Father's Day gift wouldnt it then be applicable to pay a resident fee for both. In response I get a very rude, "irregardless of who is paying, the charge is for where the golfer resides". Is there a reason to be rude about it first of all? And secondly, irregardless of who is paying?? Isn't that where you are getting your money from Harding Park? From those who are paying? Pebble, Spanish Bay, and Spyglass all would either consider waiving the fee (I've had fees waived) or at least been tactful about it. Aren't companies supposed to be based on customer service? Irregardless of money or customer service, because I don't care how much it costs I just want to have a nice day with my Dad for Father's Day, I obviously won't be golfing here for Father's Day or really any other day. Doesn't customer service distinguish the mediocre from the exceptional?
author: Jillian K.

description: I played there today. Luckily, I had a resident card. So I didnt have to pay a lot for a nice 18-hole. It was fun and challenging. The course is well groomed but a few of the the greens had bumps near the hole and it was pretty fast. So that took some adjusting. But the views are great. The staff is nice. I would play again!
author: Master C.

description: harding has done a complete 180 from its long and slow decay over the years.  the green fees are steep for non residents (around $100 on weekends), but the conditions and playablity of the course for a city muni are great.  walk ons are best when the weather is overcast or foggy.  if the sun is out, wait times can be close to a couple hours.  its a great deal for sf resident card holders.
author: Curtis Y.

description: This is a great couse with a lot of history. The old growth tree lines are beautiful. If you have a residence card, the green fees are cheap. But it's not worth it without a residence card.
author: Rob s.

description: Harding Park is a good golf experience. I play there probably once a week. The staff is friendly and the course is in good condition. My only qualms are that the driving range is off mats and the putting greens don't have holes. I understand why they have mats, I don't like it, but I understand. How much trouble is it to have actual holes on the putting green??? Honestly. It completely ruins my putting/practice experience. I hope with the President's Cup coming here in October 2009 that they can make this change because I do not think the pros are going to like hitting a metal pole on the putting green.
author: Jordan L.

description: If you can't hit the ball at least 240-250 yards, you won't have fun here. Premium on hitting the ball long and straight. You won't get any roll with the often wet conditions due to the fog. The greens fees are really high for out of towners. And its crowded on weekends (but what place isn't). Driving range is a good deal, though at $5.
author: M T.

description: For 23 million dollars it better be good. I've been playing here for over 20 years and the expensive remodel did improve the layout and the course to more modern standards-but was the bill worth it? I can play all kinds of munis that are run by pleasant people who try to make the golfer's experience a great one. To name a few: Blue Rock Springs, Vallejo; Boundary Oaks, Walnut Creek, Tilden Park, Berkeley, and Chuck Corica Earl Fry Course, Alameda. I once asked the sup at Harding why they can't put actual holes instead of sticks on the practice putting green? Answer: too much work. Why is the driving range without a way to tee up your ball? Answer: use a wooden tee and tie a string to it so it won't fly out into the range. Upkeep and turf is better than years past but who cares, I get a better value many other places. Saving grace: the 18th hole is a masterpiece worth playing once, for every Bay Area golfer. Tee time reservation system has been a problem for me, because I can never get a tee time, they say they will have online tee times soon. Great, I wonder what the extra fee will be? The city wants to say they can't run golf courses and take all the money from the green fees while they mark up "administrative fees" yet before, when the courses dumped money into the city's general fund, all the courses made money. How convenient this is to their goal which is to take away golf for the "public good" and make it less for everyman and only accessible to those few who can afford higher fees.
author: Darryl B.

description: this course is cart path only fyi. course in great condition the greens are great fairways are maintained. 18th hole is the signature hole of this course. the bad is the gun shots you will here all day long. 2 driving ranges the main range doesn't let you put a tee down for drivers. expensive course if your not a resident. food here is good
author: bo c.
